The computational study of rare phenomena has two components -- constructing models that can accurately exhibit rare and extreme events with the correct likelihoods, and developing efficient methodologies for studying their mechanisms and for estimating quantities that are sensitive to these events. In this minisymposium, we address both of these aspects from a data-driven perspective. We feature talks that learn models for rare and extreme events from data with tools from spatial statistics, graph theory, and causal inference. Rare event sampling methodologies such as importance sampling and multilevel splitting will also be discussed. Furthermore, we will also explore decision making and optimization that are robust to rare events, which is vital when data-driven procedures are used.

meeting.EventName: MS119 Efficient Uncertainty Quantification with Physics-Informed and Data-Driven Models - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Quantifying the uncertainty in a model is crucial to establishing trust in its predictions. The cost of running high-fidelity physics-based models makes proper uncertainty analysis untenable, motivating the need for data-driven surrogate models. However, data-driven models may miss critical physics and properties of the system under investigation. This minisymposium features methods for informing and constraining the underlying physics of data driven and machine-learned models for prediction and uncertainty quantification. We invite researchers to contribute talks that advance the field of physics-informed data-driven modeling for computationally efficient calibration, validation, and uncertainty quantification.

meeting.EventName: MS12 Recent Advances in Optimal Experimental Design - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Bayesian inversion is a probabilistic approach for model calibration and to solve inverse problems arising in computational science and engineering. In this method, our prior knowledge about the uncertain quantity is updated using the measurement data. The acquisition of the most informative data is of great importance since it minimizes the uncertainty and leads to the most accurate inference of the uncertain quantity in the inversion problem. Optimal design of experiments can be computationally challenging stemming from the high-dimensionality of the inversion parameters, expensive to evaluate parameter-to-observable maps, and model uncertainty additional to the uncertainty in inversion parameters. To address these challenges, solution methods are needed that are scalable, exploit problem structures, and are robust with respect to model uncertainty. In this mini-symposium, we aim to explore recent advances in optimal experimental design.

meeting.EventName: MS120 Random PDEs with Lévy Fields
meeting.EventDescription:
Uncertainty quantification plays an increasingly important role in a wide range of problems in the physical sciences and financial markets. The underlying model may be subject to various uncertainties such as parameter or domain uncertainty, model uncertainty, numerical errors, or some intrinsic stochastic variability of the model. In the latter case, the uncertainty could be either introduced by measuring instruments or is the result of insufficient observations. For realistic simulations in the underlying differential equation model this is reflected via a random operator and/or random data. These parameters are often modelled as space-time Gaussian processes, leading to continuous random functions and thin-tailed, symmetric normal distributions.
Although Gaussian random objects have convenient analytical properties, for several applications, however, it might be favourable to model the stochastic quantities as discontinuous fields or processes which also allow for asymmetric and heavy-tailed distributions. In this minisymposium we bring together researchers whose foci are on stochastic or random partial differential equations which are influenced by discontinuous fields or processes.

meeting.EventName: MS121 Advanced Multilevel and Multifidelity UQ Strategies: Applications, Generalized Model Hierarchies, and Data-Driven Approaches - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty Quantification for high-fidelity and application-relevant computations at scale remains challenging due to the extreme computational burden and the potentially large number of parameters inherent to complex physics models. Many multifidelity strategies have been introduced to circumvent these challenges, and promising results have been obtained for a variety of large-scale applications. Common to these strategies is the fusion of information with differing degrees of cost and accuracy, to ensure sufficient accuracy while reducing computational expense. This minisymposium focuses on the latest advances in multilevel and multifidelity algorithms for uncertainty quantification leveraging multiple sources of simulation and experimental data. Among the topics presented are applications to challenging industrial, nonlinear, and/or stochastic problems; methods for generalized model hierarchies including model tuning and online estimators; and data-driven approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS122 Methods for Hierarchical Bayesian Inverse Problems - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Many problems in Bayesian statistics involve the combination of complex models with sparse observed data. In such cases, the data alone might be unable to identify the model parameters and valid inferences will require significant prior information. This can be performed by specification of a hierarchical model, where extra nuisance parameters or 'hyperparameters' are used to add robustness to the prior. Computing the posterior solution via Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling is a oftentimes a challenge, since the geometry of the target posterior density can change abruptly after small variations in the hyperparameters. This minisymposium aims to cover recent advances and applications in hierarchical Bayesian inverse problems, including for instance, estimation of regularization parameters, Gibbs samplers, marginalization approaches, among others.

meeting.EventName: MS123 Uncertainty, Robustness and Safety in Deep Learning Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: There has been increasing interest in ensuring that deep learning are reliable, safe and robust. Challenges arise when models receive samples drawn from outside the training distribution. Anomalies are frequently encountered when deploying ML models in the real world. Well-calibrated predictive uncertainty estimates are indispensable for many ML applications. Generalization to unseen and worst-case inputs is also essential for robustness to distributional shift. To have ML models safely deployed in open environments, we must deepen technical understanding: 1) learning algorithms that can detect changes in data distribution and improve out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization; 2) Guide learning towards an understanding of the underlying causal mechanisms for improving robustness and generalization and enforcing distributional invariances. To achieve these goals, it is critical to dedicate substantial effort on studying key applications of robust and uncertainty-aware deep learning as well as broader ML tasks. Through the minisymposium we hope to help identify fundamentally important directions on robust and reliable ML and foster future collaborations. Topics of interest include but are not limited to: 1) Model uncertainty estimation and calibration; 2) Bayesian neural network; 3) Uncertainty-aware ML and applications; 4) Anomaly detection and OOD detection; 5) Quantifying different types of uncertainty; 6) Connections between OOD generalization and adversarial robustness

meeting.EventName: MS124 Robust and Efficient Probabilistic Deep Learning for Scientific Data and Beyond - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Deep learning is being increasingly adopted in several scientific domains due its potential to enable transformative science. However, the scientific data tends to be noisy, sparse, partly uninformative and the models themselves tend to be high-dimensional, black box and uncertain about their architecture and associated parameters. Probabilistic deep learning provides an exciting avenue to address these challenges and reason about uncertainty in order to improve their robustness and reliability for high-dimensional and unstructured data. There are two primarily classes: (a) Bayesian deep learning, where model parameters are treated as random variables and their posterior distribution is inferred from data using variational inference or Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques (b) Frequentist approaches that extend deterministic deep learning to obtain probabilistic predictions for example through interval estimates or ensembles. This minisymposium will focus on highlighting the latest advances in probabilistic deep learning, both from the Bayesian and frequentist perspective with focus on efficiency and robustness. Some of the relevant topic areas include efficient Bayesian inference in high dimensions through advances in VI, MCMC, and structural priors; reliable uncertainty estimation in deep learning; information-theoretic approaches; model ensembles; interval estimates; robustness metrics and characterizations; probabilistic programming; and applications on real-world data.

meeting.EventName: MS125 Multilevel Data Assimilation
meeting.EventDescription: In many industrial and societal applications, reliable process-model forecasts with quantified uncertainty are instrumental to obtain necessary background material before important decisions are made. Data assimilation with Monte-Carlo simulations is a means to obtain such forecasts. To obtain accurate estimates with straightforward Monte Carlo, a large number of numerical simulations is required, and many applications have corresponding process models with high computational cost. This makes it difficult to obtain the required statistical accuracy for such applications. One way to circumvent this problem is to utilize lower-fidelity models in the Monte-Carlo simulations. Use of lower fidelity models will, however, reduce the numerical accuracy of each model forecast and hence, the numerical accuracy of the data-assimilation outcome. Multilevel data assimilation uses a selection of numerical models that form hierarchies in both numerical accuracy and computational cost, and thereby tries to balance numerical and statistical errors associated with data assimilation such that the total error is minimized. This minisymposium will address recent theoretical and methodological advancements in multilevel data assimilation and illustrate these advancements with results from numerical experiments.

meeting.EventName: MS126 Information Theory, Data Assimilation and Stochastic Models for Multiscale Systems - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Complex multiscale nonlinear stochastic dynamical systems are ubiquitous in different fields. For many such systems, due particularly to their high dimensionality and partial observability, it remains a grand challenge in contemporary science and engineering to understand the underlying dynamical mechanisms and to predict their short-term and long-term behaviors. At the same time, cross-disciplinary efforts on various key issues such as coarse-grained dynamics, statistics inference, uncertainty quantification, data assimilation, and extreme-event detection, have collectively led to both more efficient algorithms and improved analytical framework. The main focus of this MS will be on the state-of-the-art advancements concerning information theory, data assimilation and stochastic/reduced-order modeling of complex multiscale nonlinear systems. We welcome contributions on topics such as Bayesian inferences and sampling, extreme events forecast, rigorous analysis of the dynamical properties, efficient numerical algorithms, effective low-dimensional surrogate models, and relevant applications.

meeting.EventName: MS127 Deep Learning for High-Dimensional Parametric PDEs - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Classical computational methods for the solution of partial differential equations (PDEs) parametrized by high-dimensional random parameters -- which are fundamental to many tasks in computational science and engineering (uncertainty quantification (UQ), Bayesian inversion, stochastic optimization, etc.)-- suffers from the curse of dimensionality. Recently, deep learning techniques have shown promise in breaking the curse of dimensionality. Successes of deep learning in data science problems have led to great interest in applying them to PDE-based problems. Data driven methodologies of machine learning may be insufficient when the underlying PDE problems have structure such as meaningful physics and conservation principles. In this minisymposium we bring together researchers at the intersection of numerical PDEs, UQ, PDE-constrained inversion and optimization, and machine learning to share recent research advances in the development of deep learning based algorithm and theory for the solution of problems related to parametric PDEs, and their applications to practical problems.

meeting.EventName: MS128 Decision Making Under Uncertainty: Supporting Technologies and Applications - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Engineering analyses ultimately serve decision making. Mitigating uncertainty however is critical to achieve robustness and in the context of complex applications computational efficiency becomes an important challenge. This mini symposium invites contributions that advances algorithms and computations in the service of decision making under uncertainty. Optimization (inverse, control, design), reinforcement learning, operator learning, reduced order modeling, and decision theoretics are example topics that will be explored for computational engineering and science applications.

meeting.EventName: MS129 Emulation and Uncertainty Quantification Under Constraints - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Computer models are an essential tool for modern scientific research and simulations are often used to understand the multiple interactions in complex physical systems. However, properly using these complex models poses additional challenges when simulations are expensive or when a single simulation can produce a large amount of information. In this minisymposium, we will discuss efficient tools and techniques for statistical uncertainty quantification, with a particular focus on settings where there is a key limitation that should be acknowledged (whether this be a particular feature of a computer model, or a limitation in the available real world data).

meeting.EventName: MS13 Theory and Simulation of Failure Probabilities and Rare Events - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: The evaluation of failure probabilities is a fundamental problem in reliability analysis and risk management of systems with uncertain inputs. We consider systems described by PDEs with random coefficients together with efficient approximation schemes. This includes stochastic finite elements, collocation, reduced basis, and advanced Monte Carlo methods. Efficient evaluation and updating of small failure probabilities and rare events remains a significant computational challenge. This minisymposium brings together tools from applied probability, numerical analysis, and computational science and engineering. We showcase advances in analysis and computational treatment of rare events and failure probabilities, including variance reduction, advanced meta-models, and multilevel Monte Carlo.

meeting.EventName: MS130 Recent Trends in Global Sensitivity Analysis in Complex Settings - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: In most application fields, analysts support their investigations through the use of quantitative models. Over the years, the computation of sensitivity (or importance) measures has become an integrating part of the analysis, allowing analysts to obtain insights on key drivers of model behavior either on a local or on a global scale. However, the estimation of global sensitivity measures may become a computationally challenging task, especially when the number of model inputs is large and the number of model evaluations one can afford is low. The estimation is considered even more challenging when the sensitivity measures require to look at the entire model output distribution. Most of the algorithms to compute sensitivity measures require special sampling schemes or additional model evaluations so that available data from previous model runs (e.g., from an uncertainty analysis based on Latin Hypercube Sampling) cannot be reused. Moreover, it often happens that input parameters cannot be modeled by independent random variables, or produce several quantities of interest, which may be scalar, but also vectorial or even functional. In this MS, we address very recent propositions from the literature, always with the aim to explore at best the behavior of a model in a complex setting, with as few model runs as possible.

meeting.EventName: MS131 Kernel Methods for Numerical Integration
meeting.EventDescription: Reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces are ubiquitous in applied mathematics and statistics due to the tractability provided by the reproducing property. They commonly underpin the theoretical analysis of stochastic processes (such as Gaussian processes) and have historically been used to construct a variety of numerical schemes, statistical tests, estimators, and sampling methods. In this minisymposium, we propose to explore recent advances in the use of kernels for numerical integration, including in the context of Bayesian numerical methods and the construction of control variates for numerical methods.

meeting.EventName: MS132 Uncertainty Quantification for Earth Remote Sensing - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Numerous Earth-observing satellites provide high-resolution and high-volume data that facilitate scientific inference on physical and environmental processes. Most remote sensing data products used for scientific investigations are often subject to multiple stages of processing before they are widely used, and the scientific utility of these data products critically depends on a comprehensive assessment of the sources of uncertainty encountered in these stages of processing. One key stage involves the use of a retrieval algorithm to infer a geophysical quantity of interest from a satellites observed intensity of radiation. This is one of a number of inverse problems used to enable inference from remote sensing data. Increasingly, science objectives are bolstered by the use of multiple remote sensing instruments with complementary goals and spatio-temporal coverage. Future instrument plans are also motivated by the information available from existing instruments and any deficiencies in scientific knowledge that can be bridged with additional remote sensing assets. The presentations in this minisymposium will highlight methodological developments to serve these goals and will span multiple Earth science applications, including weather and climate, ecosystem health, ocean composition, and surface biology and geology.

meeting.EventName: MS133 Data-Driven Approaches to Rare and Extreme Events - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Rare and extreme events are ubiquitous in a wide variety of scientific disciplines and engineering systems. The computational study of rare phenomena has two components -- constructing models that can accurately exhibit rare and extreme events with the correct likelihoods, and developing efficient methodologies for studying their mechanisms and for estimating quantities that are sensitive to these events. In this minisymposium, we address both of these aspects from a data-driven perspective. We feature talks that learn models for rare and extreme events from data with tools from spatial statistics, graph theory, and causal inference. Rare event sampling methodologies such as importance sampling and multilevel splitting will also be discussed. Furthermore, we will also explore decision making and optimization that are robust to rare events, which is vital when data-driven procedures are used.

meeting.EventName: MS134 Quantifying Predictive Uncertainty with Physics-Informed Machine Learning - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification plays a central role in verifying and validating computational models and enabling predictive science. Due to the high computational cost in modeling and simulation, it is desirable to replace the underlying physics model with data-driven surrogate models. However, such data-driven approaches do not capture critical properties and physics. This minisymposium focuses on the research and development of physics-informed, physics-constrained, and physics-guided data-driven surrogate models that also enable uncertainty quantification. We cordially invite researchers to submit work that involves or is related to computationally efficient, reliable, accurate, physics-informed, physics-constrained, physics-guided, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models and methods with an emphasis on uncertainty quantification

meeting.EventName: MS135 The Science of Hazards - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Computer modeling makes possible the simulation of hazards  from tsunamis to landslides. To make predictions of these hazard events requires many simulations in order to explore the high dimensional space of input parameters, and massive computational budgets. Data science methods are needed to detect nascent tropical storms and tsunami waves and feed information to simulation models, to monitor the evolving hazard. Hillsides denuded by wildfires are susceptible to rain-induced landslides, which can be modeled and simulated to gauge the potential threat to lives and property. In order to make predictions of hazard probability, statistical emulators can be used to estimate the output of simulations, greatly reducing the computational burden. However the inputs are often high-dimensional, and the outputs are often spatio-temporal fields. Conventional methods for constructing emulators cannot be applied in these settings. The research presented in this minisymposium examines the mathematics enabling the assessment of hazard threats from storms and tsunamis, to debris flows and lahars  the modeling and computing, emulation and forecasting. The speakers are leading scientists working on computational and statistical methodology to better predict hazards threat.

meeting.EventName: MS136 Advanced Multilevel and Multifidelity UQ Strategies: Surrogates, Forward Propagation, Inverse Problems and Optimization - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription:
Uncertainty Quantification for high-fidelity and application-relevant computations at scale remains challenging due to the extreme computational burden and the potentially large number of parameters inherent to complex physics models. Many multifidelity strategies have been introduced to circumvent these challenges, and promising results have been obtained for a variety of large-scale applications. Common to these strategies is the fusion of information with differing degrees of cost and accuracy, to ensure sufficient accuracy while reducing computational expense. This minisymposium focuses on the latest advancements in multilevel and multifidelity algorithms for uncertainty quantification leveraging multiple sources of simulation and experimental data. Among the topics presented are methods for surrogate construction; non-traditional analysis goals such as risk-averse engineering and global sensitivity analysis; and methods for inverse problems, optimization, and data assimilation.
Sandia National Laboratories is a multimission laboratory managed and operated by National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Honeywell International Inc., for the U.S. Department of Energys National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE- NA0003525.

meeting.EventName: MS137 Advances at the Interface of Uncertainty Quantification and Machine Learning - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Machine learning (ML) models have attracted a lot of attention as low cost alternatives to expensive designs. However, their deployment to high consequence problems is tricky, especially when extra sampling and processing care is needed, e.g., costly numerical simulations, risky experiments, and high stakes decision making. Essential to mitigating these risks is understanding different types of uncertainties associated with inputs and training algorithms. Therefore, Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) and decomposition methods have been employed to estimate predictive uncertainty of emerging ML models, augmenting their classical point estimates. In this minisymposium, we cover advances at the Interface of UQ and ML. In part I, we present ideas for leveraging V&V methods to assess a models credibility, optimize decisions, and identify when the model should not answer. In part II, we cover the convergence challenges of deep neural networks and examine probabilistic approaches to classical learning methods. Finally, UQ methods are incorporated into emerging learning workflows in part III. This minisymposium highlights the need for more UQ engagement in ML research, in order to provide rigorous measures of confidence, which are often overlooked by machine learning practitioners.

meeting.EventName: MS138 Uncertainty and Reliability of Machine Learning Methods - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: The past decade has seen a dramatic increase in the deployment of machine learning in many areas of science, technology, and healthcare. Machine learning models, and especially deep neural networks, have shown widespread success in a variety of tasks that otherwise require extensively trained humans with specialized expertise. Still, these models tend to fail in quite unexpected ways. This, in turn, limits the widespread application of machine learning models and complicates comparisons between approaches. We argue that uncertainty quantification is a basic step towards assessing the reliability of machine learning models (i.e., understanding under what conditions the model should not be relied upon), which is absolutely essential to the progress of the practical application of machine learning, especially for the deployment in safety-critical environments. In this mini-symposium, experts from various fields will share their perspectives on the sources and types of uncertainty present in systems employing machine learning models. They will discuss the current approaches as well as challenges of and concrete steps toward increasing the prevalence of uncertainty quantification in machine learning.

meeting.EventName: MS139 Variational Inference Bridging Application and Theory - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Bayesian inference forms a central part of uncertainty quantification in science and engineering. However, under many circumstances existing methods for representing the Bayesian posterior, such as Markov Chain Monte Carlo, are unable to keep up with the complexity of the inference problems practitioners wish to solve. This limitation broadly comes from the size of the dataset, dimension of model space, or computational cost of the forward model. Variational inference, particularly coupled with Machine Learning model approximations of science and engineering systems, is increasingly being used to better scale inference to new problems. However, many exciting research directions remain in improving the robustness and efficiency of VI and understanding how to integrate it as part of a UQ workflow that may involve Bayesian optimization, optimal experimental design, and decision making. In this minisymposium, we will bring together a diverse group of researchers from computer science, statistics, and applied mathematics to discuss recent advances in Variational Inference and similar methods along with the application of these approaches in the context of UQ for science and engineering.

meeting.EventName: MS14 Uncertainty Quantification for Data-Intensive Inverse Problems and Machine Learning - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Inverse and big-data problems are widespread in computational sciences and engineering. Despite advances in recent years on all frontiers, ranging from pure mathematical analysis to computational sciences, significant challenges remain, especially when it comes to addressing data-driven problems. In inverse/learning problems, parameters are typically related to indirect measurements by a system of partial differential equations (PDEs) or a neural network, which could be highly nonlinear and non-convex. Available indirect data are often noisy and subject to natural variation, while the unknown parameters of interest are high dimensional or possibly infinite-dimensional in principle. Bayesian inference provides a systematic framework that allows us to rigorously quantify the uncertainty in the inverse/learning problem, and to assess model validity and adequacy. Since the amount of data we wish to process is only going to increase for the foreseeable future, there is a critical need for fast and effective algorithms that integrate data with models and learning approaches that are scalable in both parameter dimension and amount of data. This minisymposium aims to attract researchers at the forefront of inverse and learning problems, data science, and data-intensive problems to present their latest work on Machine Learning methods to address the aforementioned challenges.

meeting.EventName: MS140 Advances in Measure Transport for Representing and Comparing Distributions - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Measure transport involves rearranging the mass of a reference measure in order to match a target measure. It is connected to numerous areas of pure and applied mathematics, and has in recent years become an indispensable tool in statistical applicationsin particular, for representing distributions and for defining measures of similarity between distributions. In the first case, a parametric transport map applied to samples from a simple reference measure enables efficient sampling from an otherwise intractable target probability measure. For instance, generative adversarial networks are frequently used to map a standard Gaussian distribution to a distribution over images. In the second case, two probability measures are considered to be close, for instance in Wasserstein distance, if they can be transported to each other without significant movement of mass. Despite the many recent successes of statistical and computational methods based on measure transport, important open problems remain; these include designing computational methods that achieve optimal statistical rates, developing algorithms that approximate continuous transport maps in high dimensions, and integrating measure transport techniques into larger machine learning algorithms. This minisymposium will present recent advances in all of these directions.

meeting.EventName: MS141 Uncertainty Quantification in Molecular Modeling - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Modeling the atomistic and molecular structures of a macroscopic system is a widespread and powerful tool for understanding material properties. The exact properties of a material can be modeled from first principles by invoking the laws of quantum mechanics, but solving the resulting equations induces a cost which makes practical calculations intractable for most systems of interest. Various levels of approximations are commonly employed to deliver high levels of accuracy with lesser but still significant computational cost, i.e., density functional theory (DFT) for modeling electronic structures or classical molecular dynamics (MD) for modeling nuclear motion. Practitioners interested in the macroscopic behavior of a material must typically implement additional approximate methodologies, i.e., interatomic potentials. These approximations introduce correlated structural and parametric uncertainties that impact the resulting material properties and behavior. Understanding how errors or uncertaintiesin the model and parametric choices propagate through these scales and impact macroscopic behavior is thus a critical but, to date, underdeveloped area of research. In this symposium we highlight current work addressing the uncertainties at various scales of molecular modeling, from the modeling of the atomistic structure itself through molecular simulation and estimation of resulting macroscopic uncertainties.

meeting.EventName: MS142 Challenges in Data-Driven Predictions for Safety-Critical Systems
meeting.EventDescription:
Decisions based on data-driven predictions are making an impact on an increasing number of industries. In safety-critical systems, like a ship, an offshore structure, or a spacecraft, this might be challenging. For such systems we are often faced with complex physical phenomena in environments with a high degree of uncertainty, and, in addition, we do not have sufficient experience data from safety-critical situations where the consequence of an erroneous decision can be catastrophic.
This minisymposium addresses some modern approaches for providing increased confidence in data-driven predictions, which is necessary for safety-critical applications. It explores the themes of trust, uncertainty and applications of data-driven modelling in the industry.
This could be through statistical guarantees to ensure that decisions are robust with respect to potential future scenarios. Here, the fact that relevant experience data often is scarce for safety-critical systems is a complicating factor. Methods for uncertainty reduction, such as optimal experimental design, or by encoding proper physics based prior knowledge is therefore important. There are also methods that are not directly linked to data uncertainty, for instance leveraging knowledge of the relevant physical system through causal-based constraints on the model or through explainable model diagnostics. From a more general safety perspective, this may be just as important.

meeting.EventName: MS143 Machine Learning for Design under Uncertainty - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Design optimization defines a ubiquitous class of problems across science and engineering for which uncertainty quantification plays a prominent role. Many design optimization tasks involve various scales, information at different levels of fidelity, and high dimensional decision spaces, the exploration of which often poses great challenges to computational or experimental approaches. Probabilistic machine learning methods have recently emerged as a powerful tool for synergistically combining data and mechanistic prior knowledge towards enabling the judicious exploration/exploitation of large parameter spaces, and potentially leading to the discovery of previously unknown optimal designs. This minisymposium aims to showcase current advances in machine learning for design optimization under uncertainty, including topics in Bayesian inference, deep learning, model reduction, and differentiable programming, as well as applications in diverse engineering disciplines.

meeting.EventName: MS144 New Trend in Sensitivity Analysis - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: The aim of this mini symposium is to present several new approaches to perform sensitivity analysis (SA) in order to deal and to give partial answers to the following important problems in SA. How can we perform a good SA for a model with correlated output? How can we define natural indices when the output of a model is multivariate or takes its values in a general metric space? How can we define sensitivity indices for stochastic codes? How can we perform second level SA (SA with respect to the law of the input variables)? How can we estimate classical indices (Sobol indices) using real datas (the pick freeze design of experiment is not available)and at a fixed cost (the size of the sample to estimate all order one indices does not depend on the number of input variables)? How can we perform statistical test for testing equality between Sobol indices with a unique n sample? How can we use SA for selecting variables in hierarchical models?

meeting.EventName: MS145 Sensitivity Analysis of Quantitative Systems Pharmacology Models
meeting.EventDescription:
Mathematical systems models are increasingly used to support drug development. The biotechnology/pharmaceutical (biopharma) industry calls these quantitative systems pharmacology (QSP) models. Uncertainty in QSP model predictions is important for decision-making from early discovery efforts to regulatory approval of a clinically-tested molecule. Sensitivity analysis is especially important for selecting therapeutic targets, designing additional experiments, and predicting outcomes in populations not yet tested clinically. In this session, we will present important QSP models from the biopharma industry for osteoporosis, atopic dermatitis, cholesterol, and neurological diseases. We will share a framework for applying sensitivity analysis (SA) to each of the models. The framework includes a local sensitivity analysis performed one-at-a-time, as well as the global and quasi-global sensitivity methods of Morris, partial rank correlation coefficient (PRCC), Sobol, active subspaces, and parameter subset selection.
This framework is being developed through the auspices of the Special Interest Group Mathematical and Computational Sciences (MCS) of the International Society of Pharmacometrics (ISoP). MCS has been working to integrate more mathematical SA and uncertainty quantification (UQ) methods within the biopharma community. The work presented in this minisymposium was performed by four graduate student members of the MCS Working Group on SA/UQ.

meeting.EventName: MS146 Uncertainty Quantification and Data Assimilation for Space Weather Applications - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Electronic technologies that govern modern life, such as the Global Positioning System (GPS), are deeply dependent on satellite technologies, which require accurate space weather models with quantified uncertainties to operate safely and efficiently. Uncertainties in models for the thermosphere, magnetosphere and heliosphere are wide-ranging, and can stem from how the models are driven (parameters, input conditions, external forcing) as well as from the treatment of the internal physics and numerics. For example, predictions of thermospheric density must account for model-form and parametric uncertainty in models of thermal conductivity, NO cooling, and NO binary diffusion coefficients. Moreover, to infer such model parameters and to characterize the state of the space weather system, standard data assimilation (e.g., sequential and online state and parameter estimation) and other parameter inference methods may fail due to both the limited measurements from space observatories, and their being only available as line integrals, not point measurements. Another challenge is the multiscale nature of the thermospheric density, which drops several orders of magnitude from the lower to the upper boundary of the thermosphere. This minisymposium will look at a variety of problems in the exciting application of space weather, and present a broad class of novel UQ methods to address them.

meeting.EventName: MS147 Verification Techniques in Computational Physics and Applied Mathematics - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription:
In computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes, verification and validation of the implementation and suitability of the governing equations are necessary to develop confidence in the credibility of the simulations. Verification assesses the accuracy of the solutions the code produces, relative to the assumptions and expectations of the numerical methods. Verification results also depend acutely upon the regularity of the solution. This association is delicate in the presence of singularities.
Verification can be divided into code and solution verification. Code verification focuses on the correctness of the numerical-method implementation in the code; solution verification focuses on numerical-error estimation for simulations as part of uncertainty quantification. Code verification is typically checked using manufactured and exact solutions and mesh-refinement studies. On the other hand, mesh-refinement studies are not the only techniques to perform error estimation. However, most of the proposed techniques require meshes in the so-called 'asymptotic range'. This requirement makes solution verification practically troublesome. Topics of interest include manufactured solutions, exact solutions, and other code-verification techniques, error-estimation (solution-verification) techniques, for computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes.

meeting.EventName: MS148 Physics-Informed and Data-Driven Predictive Models with Quantified Uncertainty - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification plays a crucial role in extrapolating modeling scenarios beyond currently accessible experimental domains. However, the ability to perform quality uncertainty analyses is often limited by the computational expense of underlying physics models. Though it is not unusual to replace high-fidelity models with data-driven surrogate models, they do not always adhere to important physics and mathematical properties. This minisymposium highlights state-of-the-art methods in constructing reduced-order and surrogate models that are capable of integrating physical theory, modeling, and experimental data. Techniques for constructing computationally efficient, accurate, physics-constrained, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models with quantified uncertainty are discussed. We invite researchers to submit work that involves or is related to computationally efficient, accurate, physics-informed, physics-constrained, physics-guided, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models and deep learning methods with quantified uncertainty.

meeting.EventName: MS149 Software for Uncertainty Quantification -Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) has become ubiquitous throughout the lifecycle of complex engineering systems. More often than not, progress and adoption of advanced UQ techniques relies on the availability of software features and their technical support. In this respect, cloud technologies are rapidly becoming part of the everyday workflows of companies and research facilities alike. This minisymposium aims at bringing experts in software development from all fields of uncertainty quantification. Of interest are tools that ease up individual tasks (such as surrogate modelling, sensitivity analysis, dimensionality reduction, etc.) up to general-purpose frameworks for solving UQ problems. The minisymposium is aimed at fostering discussions and exchange of ideas between developers and (prospective) users.

meeting.EventName: MS15 Uncertainty Quantification and Propagation in Climate Models - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) and propagation methods are facing a number of challenges when dealing with climate models. The curse of dimensionality, manifested by both the large number of input parameters and dense spatio-temporal outputs, together with the computational expense and non-linear behavior of components of climate models necessitates UQ method development on top of off-the-shelf approaches. This minisymposium highlights recent work on forward UQ method development, including techniques for uncertainty propagation and global sensitivity analysis, targeting the challenges above in the context of deployment for various components of earth system modeling.

meeting.EventName: MS150 Uncertainty in Material Modeling and Design - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Predicting materials behavior is a fundamental aspect of several engineering and scientific applications. In the presence of high degrees of heterogeneity in the physical environment and of uncertainty in the models and data, it is mandatory to develop new computational tools that allow for reliable predictions at large scales, while keeping the computational effort under control. In this minisymposium we will gather experts in material modeling currently working on uncertainty quantification and machine learning with the purpose of exploring the state of the art, set new research directions, and facilitate collaborations and interactions among a diverse set of speakers.

meeting.EventName: MS151 Uncertainty Quantification for Data-Intensive Inverse Problems and Machine Learning - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Inverse and big-data problems are widespread in computational sciences and engineering. Despite advances in recent years on all frontiers, ranging from pure mathematical analysis to computational sciences, significant challenges remain, especially when it comes to addressing data-driven problems. In inverse/learning problems, parameters are typically related to indirect measurements by a system of partial differential equations (PDEs) or a neural network, which could be highly nonlinear and non-convex. Available indirect data are often noisy and subject to natural variation, while the unknown parameters of interest are high dimensional or possibly infinite-dimensional in principle. Bayesian inference provides a systematic framework that allows us to rigorously quantify the uncertainty in the inverse/learning problem, and to assess model validity and adequacy. Since the amount of data we wish to process is only going to increase for the foreseeable future, there is a critical need for fast and effective algorithms that integrate data with models and learning approaches that are scalable in both parameter dimension and amount of data. This minisymposium aims to attract researchers at the forefront of inverse and learning problems, data science, and data-intensive problems to present their latest work on Machine Learning methods to address the aforementioned challenges.

meeting.EventName: MS152 IGA and Other Spline-Based Methods in UQ - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription:
The use of spline techniques in Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) and the interplay of spline-based technologies with UQ algorithms is somehow an unexplored field of research, in spite of the fact that splines are commonly used in several branches of science and engineering, such as interpolation/data fitting and Computer-Aided Design (CAD).
Splines represent an alternative to Lagrangian and orthonormal polynomials for high-dimensional functional approximation and could thus be used to approximate parameters-to-outputs maps in forward/inverse UQ (and parametric optimization) techniques. Splines also have features that one could exploit for more efficient solution of problems appearing in shape optimization under uncertainty, UQ problems with random domains, and data-fitting / data-smoothing. Finally, the use of splines of arbitrary polynomial order and continuity is at the basis of Isogeometric Analysis (IGA), which is an alternative to standard Finite Element Analysis (FEA). IGA solvers can be used straightforwardly as PDE solvers within all the standard UQ machinery, either sampling- and surrogate-model-based.
This minisymposium aims to gather scientists using spline-based methods in the context of UQ to share experience and insight on the matter.

meeting.EventName: MS153 Uncertainty Quantification for Large-Scale Scientific Data Analytics - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Scientific machine learning (SciML) and data reduction have recently received significant attention in the research communities that involve large-scale scientific data generated from either experimental or high-performance computing user facilities. The ever-increasing size of data being produced at these large facilities require sophisticated methods that account for uncertainty. For example, data used to train SciML models are often noisy, incomplete, sparse, and only partially informative. Uncertainty quantification (UQ) methods can add significant robustness to SciML and data reduction methods by alleviating over-fitting in regression, incorporating uncertainties into scientific inference, etc. This minisymposium aims to bring researchers together that have developed algorithms and theories on UQ methods for large-scale scientific data analytics. The topics of interest include but not limited to probabilistic machine learning, stochastic optimization, data assimilation, data reduction, and scientific data analytics.

meeting.EventName: MS154 Reduced Order Modelling for Forward and Inverse UQ - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Complex mathematical models appearing in engineering, physics and life science problems are unavoidably affected by uncertainties, often represented in the form of input random fields. Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) aims at treating such uncertainties and inferring on the reliability of numerical simulation outcomes. In the frameworks of forward UQ as well as inverse UQ, an essential role is played by non-intrusive sample-based methods, which typically demands for a large number of PDE solutions, each corresponding to a drawn sample of the random inputs. Those methodologies become unaffordable when the computational effort required to solve the underlying problem at a single realization of the random inputs is already considerable. To address this computational challenge, surrogates for the underlying models are constructed by means of various Model Order Reduction (MOR) techniques. This minisymposium aims to collect the most recent results as well as to provide a platform to share experience and ideas on the matter.

meeting.EventName: MS155 Uncertainty Quantification in Molecular Modeling - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Modeling the atomistic and molecular structures of a macroscopic system is a widespread and powerful tool for understanding material properties. The exact properties of a material can be modeled from first principles by invoking the laws of quantum mechanics, but solving the resulting equations induces a cost which makes practical calculations intractable for most systems of interest. Various levels of approximations are commonly employed to deliver high levels of accuracy with lesser but still significant computational cost, i.e., density functional theory (DFT) for modeling electronic structures or classical molecular dynamics (MD) for modeling nuclear motion. Practitioners interested in the macroscopic behavior of a material must typically implement additional approximate methodologies, i.e., interatomic potentials. These approximations introduce correlated structural and parametric uncertainties that impact the resulting material properties and behavior. Understanding how errors or uncertainties in the model and parametric choices propagate through these scales and impact macroscopic behavior is thus a critical but, to date, underdeveloped area of research. In this symposium we highlight current work addressing the uncertainties at various scales of molecular modeling, from the modeling of the atomistic structure itself through molecular simulation and estimation of resulting macroscopic uncertainties.

meeting.EventName: MS156 Deep Learning for Optimization - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Traditional optimization algorithms are designed to be broadly applicable tools with theoretical convergence guarantees that users from any discipline can implement off-the-shelf. A new and exciting paradigm utilizes deep neural networks (DNNs) to generate application-specific optimization algorithms, and in some cases bypasses online optimization altogether by learning a data-to-parameter mapping offline. The sacrifice of generality results in strong efficiency gains while, in some cases, retaining convergence guarantees. Learning to optimize (L2O), Learning optimal solutions, and Plug-and-play are some frameworks that have used DNNs for optimization, enjoying a surge in popularity by yielding state-of-the-art results in diverse fields including medical imaging, signal processing, power grid optimization, wireless communications, game theory and more. This minisymposium covers emerging optimization-based data driven techniques to enable innovation in computational science, engineering, and machine learning.

meeting.EventName: MS157 Decision Making Under Uncertainty: Supporting Technologies and Applications - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Engineering analyses ultimately serve decision making. Mitigating uncertainty however is critical to achieve robustness and in the context of complex applications computational efficiency becomes an important challenge. This minisymposium invites contributions that advances algorithms and computations in the service of decision making under uncertainty. Optimization (inverse, control, design), reinforcement learning, operator learning, reduced order modeling, and decision theoretics are example topics that will be explored for computational engineering and science applications.

meeting.EventName: MS158 Characterization and Prediction of Rare and Extreme Events in Complex Systems - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Characterization and prediction of rare and extreme events that correspond to large excursions is of central importance in several applications. Important examples can be found in natural phenomena such as climate, weather, oceanography and engineering systems such as structures, power grids, etc. Extreme events are not restricted to single-point quantities and often exhibit spatiotemporal extent or cross-variable interactions. Accurate characterization and reliable prediction of these events allows for realistic balancing of risks and costs in complex and expensive infrastructures. Two important challenges related to these rare and extreme events are i) limited availability of data that correspond to these rare and extreme events, leads to difficulty in quantifying tail properties for the relevant distribution, ii) determining the statistics of level crossings and durations of temporally or spatially correlated processes, and iii) incorporating information about rare and extreme events into classical inference problems. The aim of this minisymposium is to present research that address these general problems. Approaches based on, but not restricted to, statistical methods, dynamics, or a combination of both will be discussed.

meeting.EventName: MS159 Recent Trends in Global Sensitivity Analysis in Complex Settings - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: In most application fields, analysts support their investigations through the use of quantitative models. Over the years, the computation of sensitivity (or importance) measures has become an integrating part of the analysis, allowing analysts to obtain insights on key drivers of model behavior either on a local or on a global scale. However, the estimation of global sensitivity measures may become a computationally challenging task, especially when the number of model inputs is large and the number of model evaluations one can afford is low. The estimation is considered even more challenging when the sensitivity measures require to look at the entire model output distribution. Most of the algorithms to compute sensitivity measures require special sampling schemes or additional model evaluations so that available data from previous model runs (e.g., from an uncertainty analysis based on Latin Hypercube Sampling) cannot be reused. Moreover, it often happens that input parameters cannot be modeled by independent random variables, or produce several quantities of interest, which may be scalar, but also vectorial or even functional. In this MS, we address very recent propositions from the literature, always with the aim to explore at best the behavior of a model in a complex setting, with as few model runs as possible.

meeting.EventName: MS16 Physics-based Models, Machine Learning and Uncertainty Quantification - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is of great importance inmany areas of computational science and engineering. Traditional methods such as Monte Carlo (MC) to physics-based models are usually infeasible due to the very large number of forward (PDE) model evaluations needed to reach convergence. We need novel methodologies that are able to integrate traditional physics-based modeling approaches with state-of-the-art machine learning (ML) techniques. The integration of physical knowledge into ML for UQ would help us to accelerate uncertainty quantification in physics-based models. On the other hand, uncertainty quantification tools for machine/deep learning are of great interest as Bayesian methods provide a practical, robust, and reliable framework for training the networks. In this mini-symposium, we aim to explore recent advances in physics-based models, machine learning methods for uncertainty quantification, interactions between deep/reinforcement learning approaches and UQ, numerical methods, applications, and challenges in computational science and engineering.

meeting.EventName: MS160 Quantification of Uncertainties in Computational Fluid Dynamics - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription:
Despite lacking formal existence and uniqueness proofs in three dimensions, the governing equations of fluid dynamics have been used successfully for decades in simulating phenomena ranging from climate change to combustion and beyond. The nature and importance of computational fluid dynamics (CFD), and the complexity of its computational approaches, necessitate robust and reliable uncertainty quantification (UQ) methods and implementations.
Modeling for efficient forward UQ problems and treatments of backward identification of uncertainties are considered as they apply to a range of fluid dynamics problems. Special attention is devoted to multi-fidelity models, Bayesian techniques, and floating-point errors encountered in backward UQ. Machine learning as a nascent approach to CFD modeling introduces a new set of uncertainties and challenges that will also be presented.
This minisymposium aims to gather expertise and diversity of UQ perspectives to provide a comprehensive, encompassing view of the relevant algorithms and strategies pursued within the field of CFD.

meeting.EventName: MS161 History Matching and Uncertainty Quantification - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: History matching is a way of inverse modelling, or calibrating/tuning, the inputs of a complex numerical model given observations on the outputs. History matching is very different to ways of performing a Bayesian calibration. For example, the result is not a posterior distribution on the model inputs, but a set of model input points that are not implausible points given the data. It is not probabilistic. The idea is simple. A series of waves of model runs is carried out. At each wave the scaled distance (the implausibility measure) between the observations and the expected value of an emulator (either a Gaussian or a second order process) of the model for all inputs is calculated. If this distance is too large the set of inputs is ruled implausible. The scaling consists of three components:- the emulator variance (known but input dependent), the observation variance (so poor observations are downweighted compared to more accurate ones) and a variance that measures the discrepancy between the model and the real world. After the first wave a new wave of model runs is carried out in the Not Ruled Out Yet (NROY) space. A new emulator is derived and new implausibilities calculated. At each wave the emulator becomes a better fit to the model so the NROY space is progressively reduced. This minisymposium is concerned with the application and extension of history matching to a variety of applications.

meeting.EventName: MS162 Efficient Uncertainty Quantification with Physics-Informed and Data-Driven Models - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Quantifying the uncertainty in a model is crucial to establishing trust in its predictions. The cost of running high-fidelity physics-based models makes proper uncertainty analysis untenable, motivating the need for data-driven surrogate models. However, data-driven models may miss critical physics and properties of the system under investigation. This minisymposium features methods for informing and constraining the underlying physics of data driven and machine-learned models for prediction and uncertainty quantification. We invite researchers to contribute talks that advance the field of physics-informed data-driven modeling for computationally efficient calibration, validation, and uncertainty quantification.

meeting.EventName: MS163 Incorporating Structural Information in Kernel Methods - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Probabilistic and deterministic kernel methods have proven very useful and versatile for a wide range of uncertainty quantification problems in science and engineering. Such methods, while flexible in structure, are typically black-box and offer little interpretability on the scientific problem at hand. A promising solution is the integration of structural information within kernel methods, which allows for effective and interpretable learning models even with limited training data. This double minisymposium features speakers at the forefront of this important area of research in UQ. In Part I, the focus will be on the incorporation of physical laws in GP-related models. In Part II, the emphasis will be on leveraging domain knowledge in kernel-related methods, including the structural information on discontinuities, boundary information, functional data and non-Euclidean manifolds.

meeting.EventName: MS164 Uncertainty in Material Modeling and Design - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Predicting materials behavior is a fundamental aspect of several engineering and scientific applications. In the presence of high degrees of heterogeneity in the physical environment and of uncertainty in the models and data, it is mandatory to develop new computational tools that allow for reliable predictions at large scales, while keeping the computational effort under control. In this minisymposium we will gather experts in material modeling currently working on uncertainty quantification and machine learning with the purpose of exploring the state of the art, set new research directions, and facilitate collaborations and interactions among a diverse set of speakers.

meeting.EventName: MS165 Advances at the Interface of Uncertainty Quantification and Machine Learning - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Machine learning (ML) models have attracted a lot of attention as low cost alternatives to expensive designs. However, their deployment to high consequence problems is tricky, especially when extra sampling and processing care is needed, e.g., costly numerical simulations, risky experiments, and high stakes decision making. Essential to mitigating these risks is understanding different types of uncertainties associated with inputs and training algorithms. Therefore, Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) and decomposition methods have been employed to estimate predictive uncertainty of emerging ML models, augmenting their classical point estimates. In this mini-symposium, we cover advances at the Interface of UQ and ML. In part I, we present ideas for leveraging V&V methods to assess a models credibility, optimize decisions, and identify when the model should not answer. In part II, we cover the convergence challenges of deep neural networks and examine probabilistic approaches to classical learning methods. Finally, UQ methods are incorporated into emerging learning workflows in part III. This minisymposium highlights the need for more UQ engagement in ML research, in order to provide rigorous measures of confidence, which are often overlooked by machine learning practitioners.

meeting.EventName: MS166 Uncertainty, Robustness and Safety in Deep Learning Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: There has been increasing interest in ensuring that deep learning are reliable, safe and robust. Challenges arise when models receive samples drawn from outside the training distribution. Anomalies are frequently encountered when deploying ML models in the real world. Well-calibrated predictive uncertainty estimates are indispensable for many ML applications. Generalization to unseen and worst-case inputs is also essential for robustness to distributional shift. To have ML models safely deployed in open environments, we must deepen technical understanding: 1) learning algorithms that can detect changes in data distribution and improve out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization; 2) Guide learning towards an understanding of the underlying causal mechanisms for improving robustness and generalization and enforcing distributional invariances. To achieve these goals, it is critical to dedicate substantial effort on studying key applications of robust and uncertainty-aware deep learning as well as broader ML tasks. Through the minisymposium we hope to help identify fundamentally important directions on robust and reliable ML and foster future collaborations. Topics of interest include but are not limited to: 1) Model uncertainty estimation and calibration; 2) Bayesian neural network; 3) Uncertainty-aware ML and applications; 4) Anomaly detection and OOD detection; 5) Quantifying different types of uncertainty; 6) Connections between OOD generalization and adversarial robustness

meeting.EventName: MS167 Model-Based Optimal Experimental Design - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: The challenge of acquiring useful data from experimentsfor the purpose of inference, prediction, design, or controlhas received substantial attention. This task can be formalized through the framework of optimal experimental design (OED), and guided by models (whether physical or statistical) that can simulate the experimental conditions and processes. However, model-based OED faces many difficulties, such as in choosing optimality criteria, computing information metrics, quantifying uncertainties, handling nonlinear responses and non-Gaussian distributions, and accommodating expensive and dynamically evolving simulations. This minisymposium invites contributions that advance the algorithms, computations, and applications of model-based OED.

meeting.EventName: MS168 Reduced Order Modelling for Forward and Inverse UQ - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Complex mathematical models appearing in engineering, physics and life science problems are unavoidably affected by uncertainties, often represented in the form of input random fields. Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) aims at treating such uncertainties and inferring on the reliability of numerical simulation outcomes. In the frameworks of forward UQ as well as inverse UQ, an essential role is played by non-intrusive sample-based methods, which typically demands for a large number of PDE solutions, each corresponding to a drawn sample of the random inputs. Those methodologies become unaffordable when the computational effort required to solve the underlying problem at a single realization of the random inputs is already considerable. To address this computational challenge, surrogates for the underlying models are constructed by means of various Model Order Reduction (MOR) techniques. This minisymposium aims to collect the most recent results as well as to provide a platform to share experience and ideas on the matter.

meeting.EventName: MS169 Uncertainty Quantification in Molecular Modeling - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Modeling the atomistic and molecular structures of a macroscopic system is a widespread and powerful tool for understanding material properties. The exact properties of a material can be modeled from first principles by invoking the laws of quantum mechanics, but solving the resulting equations induces a cost which makes practical calculations intractable for most systems of interest. Various levels of approximations are commonly employed to deliver high levels of accuracy with lesser but still significant computational cost, i.e., density functional theory (DFT) for modeling electronic structures or classical molecular dynamics (MD) for modeling nuclear motion. Practitioners interested in the macroscopic behavior of a material must typically implement additional approximate methodologies, i.e., interatomic potentials. These approximations introduce correlated structural and parametric uncertainties that impact the resulting material properties and behavior. Understanding how errors or uncertainties in the model and parametric choices propagate through these scales and impact macroscopic behavior is thus a critical but, to date, underdeveloped area of research. In this symposium we highlight current work addressing the uncertainties at various scales of molecular modeling, from the modeling of the atomistic structure itself through molecular simulation and estimation of resulting macroscopic uncertainties.

meeting.EventName: MS17 Uncertainty Quantification for Data-Intensive Inverse Problems and Machine Learning - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Inverse and big-data problems are widespread in computational sciences and engineering. Despite advances in recent years on all frontiers, ranging from pure mathematical analysis to computational sciences, significant challenges remain, especially when it comes to addressing data-driven problems. In inverse/learning problems, parameters are typically related to indirect measurements by a system of partial differential equations (PDEs) or a neural network, which could be highly nonlinear and non-convex. Available indirect data are often noisy and subject to natural variation, while the unknown parameters of interest are high dimensional or possibly infinite-dimensional in principle. Bayesian inference provides a systematic framework that allows us to rigorously quantify the uncertainty in the inverse/learning problem, and to assess model validity and adequacy. Since the amount of data we wish to process is only going to increase for the foreseeable future, there is a critical need for fast and effective algorithms that integrate data with models and learning approaches that are scalable in both parameter dimension and amount of data. This minisymposium aims to attract researchers at the forefront of inverse and learning problems, data science, and data-intensive problems to present their latest work on Machine Learning methods to address the aforementioned challenges.

meeting.EventName: MS170 Deep Learning for High-Dimensional Parametric PDEs - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Classical computational methods for the solution of partial differential equations (PDEs) parametrized by high-dimensional random parameters -- which are fundamental to many tasks in computational science and engineering (uncertainty quantification (UQ), Bayesian inversion, stochastic optimization, etc.)-- suffers from the curse of dimensionality. Recently, deep learning techniques have shown promise in breaking the curse of dimensionality. Successes of deep learning in data science problems have led to great interest in applying them to PDE-based problems. Data driven methodologies of machine learning may be insufficient when the underlying PDE problems have structure such as meaningful physics and conservation principles. In this minisymposium we bring together researchers at the intersection of numerical PDEs, UQ, PDE-constrained inversion and optimization, and machine learning to share recent research advances in the development of deep learning based algorithm and theory for the solution of problems related to parametric PDEs, and their applications to practical problems.

meeting.EventName: MS171 Machine Learning for Design under Uncertainty - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Design optimization defines a ubiquitous class of problems across science and engineering for which uncertainty quantification plays a prominent role. Many design optimization tasks involve various scales, information at different levels of fidelity, and high dimensional decision spaces, the exploration of which often poses great challenges to computational or experimental approaches. Probabilistic machine learning methods have recently emerged as a powerful tool for synergistically combining data and mechanistic prior knowledge towards enabling the judicious exploration/exploitation of large parameter spaces, and potentially leading to the discovery of previously unknown optimal designs. This minisymposium aims to showcase current advances in machine learning for design optimization under uncertainty, including topics in Bayesian inference, deep learning, model reduction, and differentiable programming, as well as applications in diverse engineering disciplines.

meeting.EventName: MS172 Emulation and Uncertainty Quantification Under Constraints - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Computer models are an essential tool for modern scientific research and simulations are often used to understand the multiple interactions in complex physical systems. However, properly using these complex models poses additional challenges when simulations are expensive or when a single simulation can produce a large amount of information. In this minisymposium, we will discuss efficient tools and techniques for statistical uncertainty quantification, with a particular focus on settings where there is a key limitation that should be acknowledged (whether this be a particular feature of a computer model, or a limitation in the available real world data).

meeting.EventName: MS173 Data-Centric Machine Learning for Uncertainty Quantification in Complex Systems - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Multiscale models, multiphysics models, and network systems are part of complex systems, the modeling of which is computationally expensive. This expense is exacerbated when performing uncertainty quantification (UQ) studies for tasks such as inverse parameter estimation, rare events analysis, and optimal design and control. By allowing the machine learning (ML) model to assess the quality of the training data and further pick subsequent training data for optimizing performance, data-centric ML can provide a computationally tractable framework for UQ studies involving complex systems. However, several challenges such as robustness and efficiency of UQ for ML model predictions, algorithmic scalability, enforcement of physical constraints, and use of parallel computing need to be addressed for enhancing data-centric ML models in the computational sciences. This mini-symposium focuses on the recent advances in algorithms, frameworks, methodologies, and applications that promote data-centric ML in the computational sciences. Because advancing data-centric ML requires research in ML, statistics and probability, and the domain of interest, all topics directly addressing or supporting data-centric ML are welcome in this minisymposium. These include, but are not limited to, approximate inference, stochastic differential equation-driven and hybrid MCMC, quality of UQ for ML models, UQ with parallel computing, Bayesian Neural Nets, Reinforcement Learning, and applications.

meeting.EventName: MS18 Quantification of Uncertainties in Computational Fluid Dynamics - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription:
Despite lacking formal existence and uniqueness proofs in three dimensions, the governing equations of fluid dynamics have been used successfully for decades in simulating phenomena ranging from climate change to combustion and beyond. The nature and importance of computational fluid dynamics (CFD), and the complexity of its computational approaches, necessitate robust and reliable uncertainty quantification (UQ) methods and implementations.
Modeling for efficient forward UQ problems and treatments of backward identification of uncertainties are considered as they apply to a range of fluid dynamics problems. Special attention is devoted to multi-fidelity models, Bayesian techniques, and floating-point errors encountered in backward UQ. Machine learning as a nascent approach to CFD modeling introduces a new set of uncertainties and challenges that will also be presented.
This minisymposium aims to gather expertise and diversity of UQ perspectives to provide a comprehensive, encompassing view of the relevant algorithms and strategies pursued within the field of CFD.

meeting.EventName: MS19 Recent Advances in Markov Chain Monte Carlo
meeting.EventDescription: Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) methods have become a well-established tool for approximate sampling in computational statistics and are indespensible for the quantification of uncertainty. One of the main advantages of MCMC approaches, shown in numerical experiments and proven theoretically, is the robust behavior w.r.t. the dimension, such that in high-dimensional scenarios those are often the method of choice. In the recent years there have been several new advances in algorithmic as well as theoretical aspects of these methods. For instance, Wasserstein contraction in order to prove ergodicity of Markov chains, MCMC methods for inference on non-Euclidean spaces such as Riemannian manifolds, and piecewise deterministic MCMC methods which provide a new methodology at hand. The goal of this session is to discuss these recent developments and the dimension dependence of MCMC from a theoretical as well as a practical point of view.

meeting.EventName: MS2 Recent Advances in Machine Learning and Data-Driven Methods for Physical Sciences and Engineering - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Despite the remarkable growth in computational power, it remains challenging to simulate many real-world systems in full detail. Inspired by the empirical success of deep learning, many machine learning-based approaches have been proposed to tackle the computational challenge. However, unlike data-rich problems where deep learning is shown to be successful, many scientific problems allow only a limited amount of data, which limits the use of state-of-the-art deep learning algorithms. Yet, some physics principles are known a priori in many scientific problems, and how to fuse the laws of physics and recent developments of deep learning is one of the current big challenges in the scientific community. This minisymposium aims to highlight recent theoretical and algorithmic advancements in data-driven methods and deep learning techniques for uncertainty quantification and related scientific applications. The challenges include, but are not limited to, incorporating the prior physical laws, dimension reduction by auto-encoders, training of neural networks, and multi-fidelity models, altogether emphasizing applications in uncertainty quantification.

meeting.EventName: MS20 High-Dimensional Approximation and Integration using QMC and Kernel Methods - Part I of III
