meeting.EventDescription: Many applications in uncertainty quantification require tackling computational problems with very high dimensions, where often the high dimensionality comes from the need to accurately represent the underlying uncertainty. This minisymposium will bring together people working in quasi-Monte Carlo (QMC), kernel and related sampling-based methods for approximation and integration in high dimensions, with a focus on problems that are commonly encountered in UQ applications. QMC and kernel methods have recently proven successful in tackling such difficult high-dimensional problems from UQ, however, there are still many exciting avenues of research to be explored. The goal of the minisymposium is to showcase both recent theoretical developments and practical techniques for high-dimensional approximation, such as higher-order methods and methods for domain UQ, and to foster interaction between researchers working in different areas of sampling-based approximation. The minisymposium will also highlight exciting new directions for the application of QMC and kernel methods to problems in UQ outside of those where they have traditionally been applied, such as density estimation and the training of machine learning algorithms.

meeting.EventName: MS21 Shape Uncertainty Quantification Meets Shape Statistics - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Shape uncertainty quantification and shape analysis in imaging are two words which have so far not communicated much, but which actually share many similarities and challenges. In shape uncertainty quantification, the task is to describe the variability of a shape by inferring it from data and to study the propagation of this uncertainty to the behavior of a physical system. For this, domain mappings, level sets or perturbation approaches have been used. In shape statistics, one often starts from images of shapes and describes their variability. This is performed with tools such as Procrustes analysis, tangent space projection, Principal Component Analysis and its derivations such as Principal Geodesic Analysis. While a parametric description of the shape is more common in the shape uncertainty quantification community, non-parametric approaches are often used in shape statistics. Challenges in both fields are the highly nonlinear relationship between the shape and the output of the physical system or the measurement data, and the high dimensionality of the problem. Also, when using a non-parametric approach, working with shapes means working on a manifold, therefore requiring ad hoc algorithms. The goal of this minisymposium is to bring together researchers from both shape uncertainty quantification and shape analysis and to stimulate research exchange between the two fields.

meeting.EventName: MS22 Surrogate Modeling for Forward and Inverse Problems in Uncertainty Quantification - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Complex numerical models are ubiquitous in physical, atmospheric, biological, and engineering sciences. These models, often called simulators, are used to describe complicated interactions among many variables and processes in the systems and are usually accompanied by massive data. These simulators, acting as the forward model, are often required in forward propagation of uncertainty in simulation-based experiments and sensitivity analysis. In addition, we often need to extract information about parameters or unknown processes based on the simulators and data, called inverse problems. Surrogate models are often needed to reduce computational cost of forward model simulation and inverse problems. However, many surrogate modeling methods rely on the assumption of a particular parametric functional form or the assumption of Gaussian distribution, and often dont scale well with the dimensionality or adapt to the geometry of input and output spaces. Presentations in this minisymposium will highlight some latest mathematical and statistical methodological developments to address these challenges on surrogate modeling in uncertainty quantification and novel applications of surrogate models in forward simulation, calibration and inverse problems in biosciences, climate and environmental sciences.

meeting.EventName: MS23 Uncertainty Quantification for High-Dimensional Inverse Problems - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: A long-standing challenge in statistical inverse problems is the characterization of high- or even infinite-dimensional random quantities, using sampling algorithms, variational methods, and other techniques. Often the distributions of these quantities are controlled by numerical models that are computationally intensive or even intractable. Some of these challenges extend even beyond inverse problems, e.g., to the learning of high-dimensional generative models. Methods that can detect and exploit the intrinsic structure of such problems---for instance, low dimensionality or sparsity---become the key to breaking the curse of dimensionality and achieving tractable approximations. This minisymposium aims to bring together researchers working at the forefront of high-dimensional computation to share their recent adventures in high-dimensional spaces.

meeting.EventName: MS24 PDE-Constrained Optimization Under Uncertainty - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty is ubiquitous in PDE models. It is crucial to incorporate uncertainty in PDE-constrained optimization to make the optimal solution more robust and reliable. However, significant computational and theoretical challenges are faced to solve problems of PDE-constrained optimization under uncertainty (OUU), including proper formulation of the stochastic optimization problems, understanding of the well-posedness of the optimal solutions, development, and analysis of efficient and accurate approximation algorithms, etc. In this minisymposium, we bring together leading researchers to present recent advances in the formulations, theories, algorithms, and applications of PDE-constrained OUU problems.

meeting.EventName: MS25 Emulation for Coupled Multiphysics Systems
meeting.EventDescription: Many complex physical processes are modeled using more than one kind of physics which can be run as a single fully coupled system or can be loosely coupled with information passing back and forth from one simulator to the other at periodic intervals. To perform uncertainty quantification on any system, the physical simulator must be run many times to produce statistical distributions of the output quantities of interest. One way to speed up the evaluation of the simulator to produce the thousands or millions of samples needed for characterizing these distributions is reduced order modeling. In this session we focus primarily on using Gaussian stochastic process emulators (or GaSP emulators). Traditionally GaSP emulators assume an output quantity that is scalar and are developed for a single type of physics. In this minisymposium the speakers will apply emulation to coupled multiphysics systems for several different applications ranging from biomechanics to earth science and chemistry. We focus on the state of the art of emulators applied to vector output quantities for coupled process modeling.

meeting.EventName: MS26 Model-Based Optimal Experimental Design - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: The challenge of acquiring useful data from experimentsfor the purpose of inference, prediction, design, or controlhas received substantial attention. This task can be formalized through the framework of optimal experimental design (OED), and guided by models (whether physical or statistical) that can simulate the experimental conditions and processes. However, model-based OED faces many difficulties, such as in choosing optimality criteria, computing information metrics, quantifying uncertainties, handling nonlinear responses and non-Gaussian distributions, and accommodating expensive and dynamically evolving simulations. This minisymposium invites contributions that advance the algorithms, computations, and applications of model-based OED.

meeting.EventName: MS27 Learning Dynamics and the Dynamics of Learning - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Dynamical systems are one of the most important tools to model processes in science and engineering. With the increasing availability of data, there has been significant interest in developing pathways between dynamical systems and data to obtain more accurate descriptions or prediction of states in real world applications. This `Learning of dynamics' has been investigated/considered in different communities and applications, for example in data assimilation in Bayesian inversion, physics-informed neural networks, or statistical inverse problems in dynamical systems. Onthe other hand, many processes and models in modern data science and machine learning are based on underlying dynamical systems. Examples include residual neural networks, which can be related to discretization of ODEs, the stochastic gradient descent algorithm, which generates a discrete in time stochastic process, and time-dependent partial differential equations that are used for classification of graphical data.
This minisymposium on modeling and blending learning dynamics with data, will provide an inter-disciplinary platform to discuss recent developments in the respective fields, in particular differences and similarities of analytic and computational methodologies. The minisymposium aims at facilitating interdisciplinary discussions and collaborations, to create synergies and explore novel research directions.

meeting.EventName: MS28 Machine Learning Techniques for Quantifying Rare Events - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: The explosive development of machine learning (ML) is revolutionizing the arsenal of research tools in numerous fields of science. In particular, ML has opened new horizons in the study of rare events in stochastic systems, especially those coming from chemical physics applications. ML techniques enable us to access high-dimensional problems ubiquitously arising in molecular dynamics models that used to be intractable. ML approaches can be subdivided into two categories. The first category is based on the representations by neural networks (NNs).The second category comprises geometric methods. Both of them are data-driven and take advantage of intrinsic low-dimensionality of the considered dataset. Since ML methods for the study of rare events are novel and actively developing, there are many questions yet to be answered. For example, how can one control the accuracy of estimates obtained using ML methods? Which properties of fixed size datasets maximize the accuracy of the estimates? In this minisymposium, we bring together leading experts in development and analysis of ML techniques for the study of rare events as well as practitioners who use ML methods to enhance quantification of rare events in molecular dynamics models. The first session of the proposed mini-symposium is focused on geometric methods, while the second one features neural-network-based approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS29 Remote Sensing Inverse Problems for Understanding Atmospheric Greenhouse Gases - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Changing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, particularly carbon dioxide, represent a substantial perturbation to the global climate system. Understanding the resulting responses to carbon storage in the atmosphere, land, and oceans, as well as their interactions with other parts of the climate system, remains a substantial challenge in Earth science. Through global coverage and fine spatial and temporal resolution, a growing constellation of satellites are providing meaningful additional information on the carbon cycle. However, satellite observations are subject to multiple stages of processing before estimates of surface-atmosphere carbon exchange, known as fluxes, are produced. Importantly, this processing involves multiple inferences based on ill-posed inverse problems subject to several sources of uncertainty.
The first inverse problem, known as a retrieval, aims to estimate atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations from the satellite spectra. Several of the minisymposium presentations will highlight aspects of operational and/or alternative retrieval approaches and explore the computational tradeoffs for physical and statistical models of varying fidelity in the inference. Carbon cycle science investigations use the retrievals' outputs in further inference, including flux inversion. The final presentations will address additional sources of uncertainty for carbon cycle inference.

meeting.EventName: MS3 Scalable Uncertainty Quantification for Forward and Inverse Problems - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Large-scale computer simulations and correlated field observations, such as image stacks and spatio-temporal observations, are commonly used in science and engineering. The increasing computational cost of computer simulations, complex data structure, dimension and sample size are major obstacles impeding scientific discoveries and reproducibility. This minisymposium brings together researchers and experts working to advance in statistical and machine learning approaches to overcome these challenges.
This minisymposium features scalable computation and uncertainty quantification for modern computer simulations and field observations. Computationally efficient surrogate models, such as deep Gaussian processes and neural networks, provide a key step to efficiently emulate and calibrate slow, potentially nonstationary computational simulations. To further improve computational efficiency, Bayesian hierarchical models can be fit to existing simulated data in parallel to simulation runs a new approach termed in-situ uncertainty quantification. For other problems, advances in adaptive design are useful to efficiently identify failure regions and to improve reliability in computer simulations. Furthermore, new probabilistic approaches will be introduced to efficiently model high dimensional and non-Gaussian spatial data.

meeting.EventName: MS30 Verification Techniques in Computational Physics and Applied Mathematics - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription:
In computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes, verification and validation of the implementation and suitability of the governing equations are necessary to develop confidence in the credibility of the simulations. Verification assesses the accuracy of the solutions the code produces, relative to the assumptions and expectations of the numerical methods. Verification results also depend acutely upon the regularity of the solution. This association is delicate in the presence of singularities.
Verification can be divided into code and solution verification. Code verification focuses on the correctness of the numerical-method implementation in the code; solution verification focuses on numerical-error estimation for simulations as part of uncertainty quantification. Code verification is typically checked using manufactured and exact solutions and mesh-refinement studies. On the other hand, mesh-refinement studies are not the only techniques to perform error estimation. However, most of the proposed techniques require meshes in the so-called 'asymptotic range'. This requirement makes solution verification practically troublesome. Topics of interest include manufactured solutions, exact solutions, and other code-verification techniques, error-estimation (solution-verification) techniques, for computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes.

meeting.EventName: MS31 Quantifying Predictive Uncertainty with Physics-Informed Machine Learning - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification plays a central role in verifying and validating computational models and enabling predictive science. Due to the high computational cost in modeling and simulation, it is desirable to replace the underlying physics model with data-driven surrogate models. However, such data-driven approaches do not capture critical properties and physics. This minisymposium focuses on the research and development of physics-informed, physics-constrained, and physics-guided data-driven surrogate models that also enable uncertainty quantification. We cordially invite researchers to submit work that involves or is related to computationally efficient, reliable, accurate, physics-informed, physics-constrained, physics-guided, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models and methods with an emphasis on uncertainty quantification

meeting.EventName: MS32 Nonlinear Model Reduction Methods for Random or Parametric Time Dependent Problems - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Model order reduction is an effective strategy to address problems with (possibly random) parameters. The idea is to project the underlying equations onto a small finite dimensional subspace spanned by few cleverly constructed deterministic modes thus leading to a reduced size problem on which UQ or parametric analysis can be cheaply performed by e.g. sampling or quadrature techniques. However, for time dependent problems with complex dynamics, the optimal subspace on which to approximate the solution at each time instant can considerably change over time. We address in this minisymposium recent advances in model reduction for evolution problems. These include nonlinear model reduction methods or dynamical methods for the construction of time varying reduced spaces, for instance, local-adaptive-transformed reduced basis methods as well as dynamical low rank tensor approximations.

meeting.EventName: MS33 Advanced Multilevel and Multifidelity UQ Strategies: Applications, Generalized Model Hierarchies, and Data-Driven Approaches - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty Quantification for high-fidelity and application-relevant computations at scale remains challenging due to the extreme computational burden and the potentially large number of parameters inherent to complex physics models. Many multifidelity strategies have been introduced to circumvent these challenges, and promising results have been obtained for a variety of large-scale applications. Common to these strategies is the fusion of information with differing degrees of cost and accuracy, to ensure sufficient accuracy while reducing computational expense. This minisymposium focuses on the latest advances in multilevel and multifidelity algorithms for uncertainty quantification leveraging multiple sources of simulation and experimental data. Among the topics presented are applications to challenging industrial, nonlinear, and/or stochastic problems; methods for generalized model hierarchies including model tuning and online estimators; and data-driven approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS34 Methods for Hierarchical Bayesian Inverse Problems - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Many problems in Bayesian statistics involve the combination of complex models with sparse observed data. In such cases, the data alone might be unable to identify the model parameters and valid inferences will require significant prior information. This can be performed by specification of a hierarchical model, where extra nuisance parameters or 'hyperparameters' are used to add robustness to the prior. Computing the posterior solution via Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling is a oftentimes a challenge, since the geometry of the target posterior density can change abruptly after small variations in the hyperparameters. This mini-symposium aims to cover recent advances and applications in hierarchical Bayesian inverse problems, including for instance, estimation of regularization parameters, Gibbs samplers, marginalization approaches, among others.

meeting.EventName: MS35 Shape Uncertainty Quantification Meets Shape Statistics - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Shape uncertainty quantification and shape analysis in imaging are two words which have so far not communicated much, but which actually share many similarities and challenges. In shape uncertainty quantification, the task is to describe the variability of a shape by inferring it from data and to study the propagation of this uncertainty to the behavior of a physical system. For this, domain mappings, level sets or perturbation approaches have been used. In shape statistics, one often starts from images of shapes and describes their variability. This is performed with tools such as Procrustes analysis, tangent space projection, Principal Component Analysis and its derivations such as Principal Geodesic Analysis. While a parametric description of the shape is more common in the shape uncertainty quantification community, non-parametric approaches are often used in shape statistics. Challenges in both fields are the highly nonlinear relationship between the shape and the output of the physical system or the measurement data, and the high dimensionality of the problem. Also, when using a non-parametric approach, working with shapes means working on a manifold, therefore requiring ad hoc algorithms. The goal of this minisymposium is to bring together researchers from both shape uncertainty quantification and shape analysis and to stimulate research exchange between the two fields.

meeting.EventName: MS36 Surrogate Modeling for Forward and Inverse Problems in Uncertainty Quantification - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Complex numerical models are ubiquitous in physical, atmospheric, biological, and engineering sciences. These models, often called simulators, are used to describe complicated interactions among many variables and processes in the systems and are usually accompanied by massive data. These simulators, acting as the forward model, are often required in forward propagation of uncertainty in simulation-based experiments and sensitivity analysis. In addition, we often need to extract information about parameters or unknown processes based on the simulators and data, called inverse problems. Surrogate models are often needed to reduce computational cost of forward model simulation and inverse problems. However, many surrogate modeling methods rely on the assumption of a particular parametric functional form or the assumption of Gaussian distribution, and often dont scale well with the dimensionality or adapt to the geometry of input and output spaces. Presentations in this mini-symposium will highlight some latest mathematical and statistical methodological developments to address these challenges on surrogate modeling in uncertainty quantification and novel applications of surrogate models in forward simulation, calibration and inverse problems in biosciences, climate and environmental sciences.

meeting.EventName: MS37 Uncertainty Quantification for Large-Scale Scientific Data Analytics - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Scientific machine learning (SciML) and data reduction have recently received significant attention in the research communities that involve large-scale scientific data generated from either experimental or high-performance computing user facilities. The ever-increasing size of data being produced at these large facilities require sophisticated methods that account for uncertainty. For example, data used to train SciML models are often noisy, incomplete, sparse, and only partially informative. Uncertainty quantification (UQ) methods can add significant robustness to SciML and data reduction methods by alleviating over-fitting in regression, incorporating uncertainties into scientific inference, etc. This mini-symposium aims to bring researchers together that have developed algorithms and theories on UQ methods for large-scale scientific data analytics. The topics of interest include but not limited to probabilistic machine learning, stochastic optimization, data assimilation, data reduction, and scientific data analytics.

meeting.EventName: MS38 Information Theory, Data Assimilation and Stochastic Models for Multiscale Systems - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Complex multiscale nonlinear stochastic dynamical systems are ubiquitous in different fields. For many such systems, due particularly to their high dimensionality and partial observability, it remains a grand challenge in contemporary science and engineering to understand the underlying dynamical mechanisms and to predict their short-term and long-term behaviors. At the same time, cross-disciplinary efforts on various key issues such as coarse-grained dynamics, statistics inference, uncertainty quantification, data assimilation, and extreme-event detection, have collectively led to both more efficient algorithms and improved analytical framework. The main focus of this MS will be on the state-of-the-art advancements concerning information theory, data assimilation and stochastic/reduced-order modeling of complex multiscale nonlinear systems. We welcome contributions on topics such as Bayesian inferences and sampling, extreme events forecast, rigorous analysis of the dynamical properties, efficient numerical algorithms, effective low-dimensional surrogate models, and relevant applications.

meeting.EventName: MS39 Statistical Surrogate Modeling and Optimization for Stochastic Simulation - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Historically, design and analysis of computer experiments focused on deterministic solvers from the physical sciences via Gaussian process interpolation. But nowadays computer modeling is common in the social, management and biological sciences, where stochastic simulations abound. This minisymposium brings together a selection of researchers in the areas of statistical surrogate modeling, active learning, and Bayesian optimization of stochastic computer models, simulation campaigns, and high volume observational studies. Noisier simulations demand bigger experiments to isolate signal from noise, and more sophisticated surrogate models  such as adding a variance processes to track changes in noise throughout the input space, or relaxing the Gaussian assumptions. Appropriate surrogate modeling is key to the propagation of uncertainty to decision criteria underlying important large-scale and real time control of systems which rely on expensive simulation campaigns. Think of estimating the stretching effect in observing the light of far-away galaxies with future satellite campaigns, from existing incomplete data and realistic synthetic data. Or similarly the combination of limited data on disease spread combined with fine-grained simulation of epidemiological dynamics and entertainment of intervention strategies such as vaccination or quarantine. The talks will be on these methodologies applied in those challenging modeling and optimization of large scale real-world problems.

meeting.EventName: MS4 Nonlinear Model Reduction Methods for Random or Parametric Time Dependent Problems - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Model order reduction is an effective strategy to address problems with (possibly random) parameters. The idea is to project the underlying equations onto a small finite dimensional subspace spanned by few cleverly constructed deterministic modes thus leading to a reduced size problem on which UQ or parametric analysis can be cheaply performed by e.g. sampling or quadrature techniques. However, for time dependent problems with complex dynamics, the optimal subspace on which to approximate the solution at each time instant can considerably change over time. We address in this minisymposium recent advances in model reduction for evolution problems. These include nonlinear model reduction methods or dynamical methods for the construction of time varying reduced spaces, for instance, local-adaptive-transformed reduced basis methods as well as dynamical low rank tensor approximations.

meeting.EventName: MS40 Sample-Efficient Sequential Decision Making Under Uncertainty - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Deducing meaningful decisions from posterior belief is the hallmark of intelligent systems. As such, sequential decision making defines an important branch of modern machine learning in which uncertainty quantification plays a prominent role. The Bayesian formalism offers a natural setting for reasoning under uncertainty, allowing one to cast many sequential decision making tasks into Bayesian optimization and bandit problems. Such techniques have emerged as powerful tools for enabling the judicious exploration of large design/parameter spaces using only a small number of experimental trials; a ubiquitous task across all corners of science and engineering. This mini-symposium invites contributions proposing methodological advances in sequential decision making and optimal experimental design, as well as applications in automated experimentation, design optimization and optimal control.

meeting.EventName: MS41 Advanced Methods for High Dimensional Bayesian Inference and Nonlinear Filtering - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Many real world problems involving stochastic-dynamic systems are facing increasing demands on both the resolution and quality of predictions or representations of these systems. This is in no small part driven by the ever increasing volume of data available for many applications, as well as rapidly developing computational power. In order to keep pace with such requirements, methods for optimally combining data and prior knowledge in a computationally efficient manner are of utmost importance. An active area of research is in methods that balance computational cost and accuracy in the challenging setting of high dimensional stochastic-dynamic systems with partial observations and uncertainties best quantified by non-Gaussian distributions. Such problems are investigated in closely related sub-fields of Bayesian inverse problems, nonlinear filtering, variational inference and data assimilation.
This mini-symposium brings together researchers working on both the theoretical properties and algorithmic developments of such methods. It aims to foster the cross-pollination of ideas for computationally efficient approximate Bayesian inference from e.g. multi-level Monte Carlo, sparse approximations and ensemble based filtering with techniques for learning in an uncertain environment (e.g. reinforcement learning).

meeting.EventName: MS42 Data-Centric Machine Learning for Uncertainty Quantification in Complex Systems - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Multiscale models, multiphysics models, and network systems are part of complex systems, the modeling of which is computationally expensive. This expense is exacerbated when performing uncertainty quantification (UQ) studies for tasks such as inverse parameter estimation, rare events analysis, and optimal design and control. By allowing the machine learning (ML) model to assess the quality of the training data and further pick subsequent training data for optimizing performance, data-centric ML can provide a computationally tractable framework for UQ studies involving complex systems. However, several challenges such as robustness and efficiency of UQ for ML model predictions, algorithmic scalability, enforcement of physical constraints, and use of parallel computing need to be addressed for enhancing data-centric ML models in the computational sciences. This mini-symposium focuses on the recent advances in algorithms, frameworks, methodologies, and applications that promote data-centric ML in the computational sciences. Because advancing data-centric ML requires research in ML, statistics and probability, and the domain of interest, all topics directly addressing or supporting data-centric ML are welcome in this minisymposium. These include, but are not limited to, approximate inference, stochastic differential equation-driven and hybrid MCMC, quality of UQ for ML models, UQ with parallel computing, Bayesian Neural Nets, Reinforcement Learning, and applications.

meeting.EventName: MS43 Operator Learning for Uncertainty Quantification - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Operator learning techniques have recently emerged as a powerful tool for learning mappings between infinite-dimensional function spaces. Techniques such as deep operator networks, the family of neural operator methods, and operator-valued kernel methods have demonstrated promise in building fast surrogate models for emulating complex physical processes, opening new avenues for sampling, inference and uncertainty quantification in very high-dimensional parameter spaces. This mini-symposium invites contributions that demonstrate the power of operator learning methods in the context of uncertainty quantification, from both a methodological and applications point of view.

meeting.EventName: MS44 Uncertainty Quantification and Parameter Estimation in Climate Models - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Parameter estimation or inverse UQ methods for climate models are challenged by both the large number of input parameters and high-dimensional, dense spatio-temporal outputs, even if the complex climate models are replaced with pre-constructed surrogates. Uncertainty assessment is further challenged by the structural errors stemming from imperfect knowledge of physics. This minisymposium highlights recent work on inverse UQ method development, including techniques for parameter estimation and model calibration in the context of deployment for various components of earth system modeling.

meeting.EventName: MS45 Recent Advances in Machine Learning and Data-Driven Methods for Physical Sciences and Engineering - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Despite the remarkable growth in computational power, it remains challenging to simulate many real-world systems in full detail. Inspired by the empirical success of deep learning, many machine learning-based approaches have been proposed to tackle the computational challenge. However, unlike data-rich problems where deep learning is shown to be successful, many scientific problems allow only a limited amount of data, which limits the use of state-of-the-art deep learning algorithms. Yet, some physics principles are known a priori in many scientific problems, and how to fuse the laws of physics and recent developments of deep learning is one of the current big challenges in the scientific community. This minisymposium aims to highlight recent theoretical and algorithmic advancements in data-driven methods and deep learning techniques for uncertainty quantification and related scientific applications. The challenges include, but are not limited to, incorporating the prior physical laws, dimension reduction by auto-encoders, training of neural networks, and multi-fidelity models, altogether emphasizing applications in uncertainty quantification.

meeting.EventName: MS46 Scalable Uncertainty Quantification for Forward and Inverse Problems - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Large-scale computer simulations and correlated field observations, such as image stacks and spatio-temporal observations, are commonly used in science and engineering. The increasing computational cost of computer simulations, complex data structure, dimension and sample size are major obstacles impeding scientific discoveries and reproducibility. This minisymposium brings together researchers and experts working to advance in statistical and machine learning approaches to overcome these challenges.
This minisymposium features scalable computation and uncertainty quantification for modern computer simulations and field observations. Computationally efficient surrogate models, such as deep Gaussian processes and neural networks, provide a key step to efficiently emulate and calibrate slow, potentially nonstationary computational simulations. To further improve computational efficiency, Bayesian hierarchical models can be fit to existing simulated data in parallel to simulation runs a new approach termed in-situ uncertainty quantification. For other problems, advances in adaptive design are useful to efficiently identify failure regions and to improve reliability in computer simulations. Furthermore, new probabilistic approaches will be introduced to efficiently model high dimensional and non-Gaussian spatial data.

meeting.EventName: MS47 Software for Uncertainty Quantification - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) has become ubiquitous throughout the lifecycle of complex engineering systems. More often than not, progress and adoption of advanced UQ techniques relies on the availability of software features and their technical support. In this respect, cloud technologies are rapidly becoming part of the everyday workflows of companies and research facilities alike. This minisymposium aims at bringing experts in software development from all fields of uncertainty quantification. Of interest are tools that ease up individual tasks (such as surrogate modelling, sensitivity analysis, dimensionality reduction, etc.) up to general-purpose frameworks for solving UQ problems. The minisymposium is aimed at fostering discussions and exchange of ideas between developers and (prospective) users.

meeting.EventName: MS48 Multilevel and Multifidelity Monte Carlo - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Multilevel and multifidelity Monte Carlo are a powerful class of methods which aim to reduce the computational complexity of Monte Carlo in the context where approximation is required before simulation, which is particularly relevant to UQ for science and engineering applications. Specifically they reduce the cost for attaining a given mean squared error by leveraging approximate models over a range of accuracy/fidelity.
The purpose of this minisymposium is to bring together academics, working on the development and application of such methods. A particular focus of the session is on Bayesian computation, which covers topics such as MCMC, sequential Monte Carlo/filtering and Bayesian inverse problems to name a few. It will also cover recent novel applications to forward UQ, with an aim towards synergy between forward and inverse techniques.

meeting.EventName: MS49 Optimal Transport in Uncertainty Quantification and Learning - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Optimal transport has gained much attention in recent years due to its many applications in data science, imaging, and geometry. In addition, optimal transport has proved a useful tool in quantifying uncertainty in parameters or models in a consistent and measure theoretic way. The aim of this mini-symposium is to highlight connections between uncertainty quantification and machine learning through optimal transport, with speakers from applied mathematics, engineering and computer science, working both in theory and applications

meeting.EventName: MS5 Multilevel and Multifidelity Monte Carlo - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Multilevel and multifidelity Monte Carlo are a powerful class of methods which aim to reduce the computational complexity of Monte Carlo in the context where approximation is required before simulation, which is particularly relevant to UQ for science and engineering applications. Specifically they reduce the cost for attaining a given mean squared error by leveraging approximate models over a range of accuracy/fidelity.
The purpose of this minisymposium is to bring together academics, working on the development and applicationof such methods. A particular focus of the session is on Bayesian computation, which covers topics such as MCMC, sequential Monte Carlo/filtering and Bayesian inverse problems to name a few. It will also cover recent novel applications to forward UQ, with an aim towards synergy between forward and inverse techniques.

meeting.EventName: MS50 IGA and Other Spline-Based Methods in UQ - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription:
The use of spline techniques in Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) and the interplay of spline-based technologies with UQ algorithms is somehow an unexplored field of research, in spite of the fact that splines are commonly used in several branches of science and engineering, such as interpolation/data fitting and Computer-Aided Design (CAD).
Splines represent an alternative to Lagrangian and orthonormal polynomials for high-dimensional functional approximation and could thus be used to approximate parameters-to-outputs maps in forward/inverse UQ (and parametric optimization) techniques. Splines also have features that one could exploit for more efficient solution of problems appearing in shape optimization under uncertainty, UQ problems with random domains, and data-fitting / data-smoothing. Finally, the use of splines of arbitrary polynomial order and continuity is at the basis of Isogeometric Analysis (IGA), which is an alternative to standard Finite Element Analysis (FEA). IGA solvers can be used straightforwardly as PDE solvers within all the standard UQ machinery, either sampling- and surrogate-model-based.
This minisymposium aims to gather scientists using spline-based methods in the context of UQ to share experience and insight on the matter.

meeting.EventName: MS51 Variational Inference Bridging Application and Theory - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Bayesian inference forms a central part of uncertainty quantification in science and engineering. However, under many circumstances existing methods for representing the Bayesian posterior, such as Markov Chain Monte Carlo, are unable to keep up with the complexity of the inference problems practitioners wish to solve. This limitation broadly comes from the size of the dataset, dimension of model space, or computational cost of the forward model. Variational inference, particularly coupled with Machine Learning model approximations of science and engineering systems, is increasingly being used to better scale inference to new problems. However, many exciting research directions remain in improving the robustness and efficiency of VI and understanding how to integrate it as part of a UQ workflow that may involve Bayesian optimization, optimal experimental design, and decision making. In this minisymposium, we will bring together a diverse group of researchers from computer science, statistics, and applied mathematics to discuss recent advances in Variational Inference and similar methods along with the application of these approaches in the context of UQ for science and engineering.

meeting.EventName: MS52 Uncertainty Quantification for High-Dimensional Inverse Problems - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: A long-standing challenge in statistical inverse problems is the characterization of high- or even infinite-dimensional random quantities, using sampling algorithms, variational methods, and other techniques. Often the distributions of these quantities are controlled by numerical models that are computationally intensive or even intractable. Some of these challenges extend even beyond inverse problems, e.g., to the learning of high-dimensional generative models. Methods that can detect and exploit the intrinsic structure of such problems---for instance, low dimensionality or sparsity---become the key to breaking the curse of dimensionality and achieving tractable approximations. This mini-symposium aims to bring together researchers working at the forefront of high-dimensional computation to share their recent adventures in high-dimensional spaces.

meeting.EventName: MS53 PDE-Constrained Optimization Under Uncertainty - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty is ubiquitous in PDE models. It is crucial to incorporate uncertainty in PDE-constrained optimization to make the optimal solution more robust and reliable. However, significant computational and theoretical challenges are faced to solve problems of PDE-constrained optimization under uncertainty (OUU), including proper formulation of the stochastic optimization problems, understanding of the well-posedness of the optimal solutions, development, and analysis of efficient and accurate approximation algorithms, etc. In this minisymposium, we bring together leading researchers to present recent advances in the formulations, theories, algorithms, and applications of PDE-constrained OUU problems.

meeting.EventName: MS54 Bayesian Calibration and Machine Learning Methods for Uncertainty Quantification - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
This minisymposium is devoted to recent developments in computations, methodologies, and applications for Uncertainty Quantification (UQ) in complex physical systems. Inference about the physical process in the presence of the high-volume output and model uncertainty is challenging, since appropriate uncertainty assessment is the key success to understand the physical process of interest. In the calibration context, the discrepancy between reality and simulators are difficulty to model. In the inverse problem setting, the high-dimensional input space can make the Bayesian inverse computationally challenging. With massive amount of datasets, efficient computations are required.
Bringing selected leading researchers, this minisymposium has been broken into two sessions: Bayesian calibration (Part I) and machine learning methods (Part II). Research topics are focused on addressing computational and modeling issues in UQ with tools including approximation Bayesian computation, neural networks, and Gaussian processes. It includes a diverse mix of gender-balanced speakers with experience level including PhD student, early-career and mid-career researchers as well as well-established scholars such as Peter Challenor with backgrounds in statistics, operational research, and engineering. We hope this minisymposium will serve as a nexus to exchange ideas to address UQ problems with various machine learning and Bayesian learning tools.

meeting.EventName: MS55 Recent Advances in Optimal Experimental Design - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Bayesian inversion is a probabilistic approach for model calibration and to solve inverse problems arising in computational science and engineering. In this method, our prior knowledge about the uncertain quantity is updated using the measurement data. The acquisition of the most informative data is of great importance since it minimizes the uncertainty and leads to the most accurate inference of the uncertain quantity in the inversion problem. Optimal design of experiments can be computationally challenging stemming from the high-dimensionality of the inversion parameters, expensive to evaluate parameter-to-observable maps, and model uncertainty additional to the uncertainty in inversion parameters. To address these challenges, solution methods are needed that are scalable, exploit problem structures, and are robust with respect to model uncertainty. In this mini-symposium, we aim to explore recent advances in optimal experimental design.

meeting.EventName: MS56 Theory and Simulation of Failure Probabilities and Rare Events - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: The evaluation of failure probabilities is a fundamental problem in reliability analysis and risk management of systems with uncertain inputs. We consider systems described by PDEs with random coefficients together with efficient approximation schemes. This includes stochastic finite elements, collocation, reduced basis, and advanced Monte Carlo methods. Efficient evaluation and updating of small failure probabilities and rare events remains a significant computational challenge. This minisymposium brings together tools from applied probability, numerical analysis, and computational science and engineering. We showcase advances in analysis and computational treatment of rare events and failure probabilities, including variance reduction, advanced meta-models, and multilevel Monte Carlo.

meeting.EventName: MS57 Machine Learning Techniques for Quantifying Rare Events - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: The explosive development of machine learning (ML) is revolutionizing the arsenal of research tools in numerous fields of science. In particular, ML has opened new horizons in the study of rare events in stochastic systems, especially those coming from chemical physics applications. ML techniques enable us to access high-dimensional problems ubiquitously arising in molecular dynamics models that used to be intractable. ML approaches can be subdivided into two categories. The first category is based on the representations by neural networks (NNs).The second category comprises geometric methods. Both of them are data-driven and take advantage of intrinsic low-dimensionality of the considered dataset. Since ML methods for the study of rare events are novel and actively developing, there are many questions yet to be answered. For example, how can one control the accuracy of estimates obtained using ML methods? Which properties of fixed size datasets maximize the accuracy of the estimates? In this minisymposium, we bring together leading experts in development and analysis of ML techniques for the study of rare events as well as practitioners who use ML methods to enhance quantification of rare events in molecular dynamics models. The first session of the proposed mini-symposium is focused on geometric methods, while the second one features neural-network-based approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS58 Uncertainty Quantification and Propagation in Climate Models - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) and propagation methods are facing a number of challenges when dealing with climate models. The curse of dimensionality, manifested by both the large number of input parameters and dense spatio-temporal outputs, together with the computational expense and non-linear behavior of components of climate models necessitates UQ method development on top of off-the-shelf approaches. This minisymposium highlights recent work on forward UQ method development, including techniques for uncertainty propagation and global sensitivity analysis, targeting the challenges above in the context of deployment for various components of earth system modeling.

meeting.EventName: MS59 Physics-Based Models, Machine Learning and Uncertainty Quantification - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification (UQ) is of great importance in many areas of computational science and engineering. Traditional methods such as Monte Carlo (MC) to physics-based models are usually infeasible due to the very large number of forward (PDE) model evaluations needed to reach convergence. We need novel methodologies that are able to integrate traditional physics-based modeling approaches with state-of-the-art machine learning (ML) techniques. The integration of physical knowledge into ML for UQ would help us to accelerate uncertainty quantification in physics-based models. On the other hand, uncertainty quantification tools for machine/deep learning are of great interest as Bayesian methods provide a practical, robust, and reliable framework for training the networks. In this mini-symposium, we aim to explore recent advances in physics-based models, machine learning methods for uncertainty quantification, interactions between deep/reinforcement learning approaches and UQ, numerical methods, applications, and challenges in computational science and engineering.

meeting.EventName: MS6 Optimal Transport in Uncertainty Quantification and Learning - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Optimal transport has gained much attention in recent years due to its many applications in data science, imaging, and geometry. In addition, optimal transport has proved a useful tool in quantifying uncertainty in parameters or models in a consistent and measure theoretic way. The aim of this minisymposium is to highlight connections between uncertainty quantification and machine learning through optimal transport, with speakers from applied mathematics, engineering and computer science, working both in theory and applications

meeting.EventName: MS60 Physics-Informed and Data-Driven Predictive Models with Quantified Uncertainty - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty quantification plays a crucial role in extrapolating modeling scenarios beyond currently accessible experimental domains. However, the ability to perform quality uncertainty analyses is often limited by the computational expense of underlying physics models. Though it is not unusual to replace high-fidelity models with data-driven surrogate models, they do not always adhere to important physics and mathematical properties. This minisymposium highlights state-of-the-art methods in constructing reduced-order and surrogate models that are capable of integrating physical theory, modeling, and experimental data. Techniques for constructing computationally efficient, accurate, physics-constrained, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models with quantified uncertainty are discussed. We invite researchers to submit work that involves or is related to computationally efficient, accurate, physics-informed, physics-constrained, physics-guided, and data- and domain-informed surrogate models and deep learning methods with quantified uncertainty.

meeting.EventName: MS61 Sampling via Variational Methods - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: The need of fusing data with models in modern UQ and machine learning has caused statistical inference methods to receive considerable attention in recent years and has led to various advancements in the field. Sampling algorithms are pervasive in Bayesian methods and are also essential in performing uncertainty assessment. This minisymposium addresses the problem of generating samples from a given target distribution with particular attention paid to Bayesian inverse problems. We focus on methodologies based on a variational formulation and solved with the help of tools from optimization, including (but not restricted to) Particle Methods, Stein variational gradient descent, Langevin flows, Transport methods and Normalizing flows. Typical challenges include the choice of a suitable objective function and function space as well as the numerical approximation of the resulting flows in the space of probability measures. The aim of the minisymposium is to bring together experts from different areas to explore a broad range of recent techniques both from a theoretical and an algorithmic perspective.

meeting.EventName: MS62 Advanced Multilevel and Multifidelity UQ Strategies: Surrogates, Forward Propagation, Inverse Problems and Optimization - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription:
Uncertainty Quantification for high-fidelity and application-relevant computations at scale remains challenging due to the extreme computational burden and the potentially large number of parameters inherent to complex physics models. Many multifidelity strategies have been introduced to circumvent these challenges, and promising results have been obtained for a variety of large-scale applications. Common to these strategies is the fusion of information with differing degrees of cost and accuracy, to ensure sufficient accuracy while reducing computational expense. This minisymposium focuses on the latest advancements in multilevel and multifidelity algorithms for uncertainty quantification leveraging multiple sources of simulation and experimental data. Among the topics presented are methods for surrogate construction; non-traditional analysis goals such as risk-averse engineering and global sensitivity analysis; and methods for inverse problems, optimization, and data assimilation.
Sandia National Laboratories is a multimission laboratory managed and operated by National Technology & Engineering Solutions of Sandia, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Honeywell International Inc., for the U.S. Department of Energys National Nuclear Security Administration under contract DE- NA0003525.

meeting.EventName: MS63 High-Dimensional Approximation and Integration using QMC and Kernel Methods - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Many applications in uncertainty quantification require tackling computational problems with very high dimensions, where often the high dimensionality comes from the need to accurately represent the underlying uncertainty. This minisymposium will bring together people working in quasi-Monte Carlo (QMC), kernel and related sampling-based methods for approximation and integration in high dimensions, with a focus on problems that are commonly encountered in UQ applications. QMC and kernel methods have recently proven successful in tackling such difficult high-dimensional problems from UQ, however, there are still many exciting avenues of research to be explored. The goal of the minisymposium is to showcase both recent theoretical developments and practical techniques for high-dimensional approximation, such as higher-order methods and methods for domain UQ, and to foster interaction between researchers working in different areas of sampling-based approximation. The minisymposium will also highlight exciting new directions for the application of QMC and kernel methods to problems in UQ outside of those where they have traditionally been applied, such as density estimation and the training of machine learning algorithms.

meeting.EventName: MS64 Operator Learning in PDEs, Inverse Problems, and UQ - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription: Operators that map functions to functions are fundamental in science and engineering, often modeling physical laws or complex engineering systems, and it is desirable to learn such operators for the purpose of scientific discovery or surrogate modeling. This is especially relevant for inverse problems, as not only is the act of learning itself an inverse problem, but once an efficient and scalable surrogate operator is learned, it can then be used to accelerate expensive inverse computations such as UQ, Bayesian inversion, and optimal design, or even directly output the inverse problem solution. Although model-driven and physics-based approaches were originally developed for these tasks, in recent years data-driven methods have also exhibited remarkable success. However, the mathematical understanding of learning operators from data, including estimation, approximation, and optimization errors, is still in its infancy. This minisymposium brings together researchers working in statistical machine learning, approximation theory, Bayesian inference, and PDEs to discuss recent theoretical and methodological advances in operator learning motivated by both forward and inverse problems.

meeting.EventName: MS65 Robust and Efficient Probabilistic Deep Learning for Scientific data and Beyond - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Deep learning is being increasingly adopted in several scientific domains due its potential to enable transformative science. However, the scientific data tends to be noisy, sparse, partly uninformative and the models themselves tend to be high-dimensional, black box and uncertain about their architecture and associated parameters. Probabilistic deep learning provides an exciting avenue to address these challenges and reason about uncertainty in order to improve their robustness and reliability for high-dimensional and unstructured data. There are two primarily classes: (a) Bayesian deep learning, where model parameters are treated as random variables and their posterior distribution is inferred from data using variational inference or Markov chain Monte Carlo techniques (b) Frequentist approaches that extend deterministic deep learning to obtain probabilistic predictions for example through interval estimates or ensembles. This minisymposium will focus on highlighting the latest advances in probabilistic deep learning, both from the Bayesian and frequentist perspective with focus on efficiency and robustness. Some of the relevant topic areas include efficient Bayesian inference in high dimensions through advances in VI, MCMC, and structural priors; reliable uncertainty estimation in deep learning; information-theoretic approaches; model ensembles; interval estimates; robustness metrics and characterizations; probabilistic programming; and applications on real-world data.

meeting.EventName: MS66 New Developments in Gaussian Processes
meeting.EventDescription:
Gaussian processes (GPs) are used in many applications, including modeling of natural processes, regression, classification, and interpolation of computer output. Their popularity is in part because they provide conceptual and computational advantages, and in part because they are useful building blocks for hierarchical models. However, many pressing questions concerning the modeling and computation with GPs are still unresolved, and new progress calls for novel ideas at the intersection of applied mathematics and statistics.
GP modeling involves specifying a covariance function, which is usually unknown and assumed to fall into some parametric class. Developing new efficient ways of specifying non-separable and anisotropic covariance models is essential to the future success of GPs in uncertainty quantification, and particularly so in high dimensional settings.
Computationally, GPs require a Cholesky factorization of the covariance matrix, which is costly for large datasets. While this tractability issue has been widely studied, new promising classes of approximation are emerging, prompting a renewed interest in GPs. These computational advances have opened new foundational questions, as we lack a full understanding of their effect in the estimation error.
This symposium will bring together applied mathematicians and statisticians to address some of the modeling, computational and foundational open questions in GPs.

meeting.EventName: MS67 Metamodel-Based Approaches for Robust (Stochastic) Inversion and Optimization - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: This minisymposium aims at providing an overview of recent advances regarding both theoretical issues and applied aspects of two canonical problems in uncertainty quantification: namely, robust inversion and robust optimization. These two classes of problems are frequently encountered in several applied fields, from reliability and risk assessment to robust and reliable design. Inversion consists in the identification of the set of input values leading to a given output threshold exceedance. It is sometimes known as excursion set identification. Robustness appears as soon as uncontrollable variables (typically, environmental parameters) have to be handled, leading to the so-called "robust inversion" paradigm. In the optimization field, uncertainties can be inserted at every stage and several formulations can be considered. Robust (or stochastic) optimization plays a fundamental role in several applied fields. For some cases, inversion and robust optimization can be intertwined and strong links can be highlighted between them. The scope here is to present new trends of research, especially in the unifying context of metamodel-based approaches seen as a powerful framework for tackling both robust inversion and optimization in the context of costly numerical simulators. Theoretical developments, computational methods and related software, as well as challenging applications, will serve as an illustration of the current breadth and liveliness of these research fields.

meeting.EventName: MS68 Statistical Surrogate Modeling and Optimization for Stochastic Simulation - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Historically, design and analysis of computer experiments focused on deterministic solvers from the physical sciences via Gaussian process interpolation. But nowadays computer modeling is common in the social, management and biological sciences, where stochastic simulations abound. This minisymposium brings together a selection of researchers in the areas of statistical surrogate modeling, active learning, and Bayesian optimization of stochastic computer models, simulation campaigns, and high volume observational studies. Noisier simulations demand bigger experiments to isolate signal from noise, and more sophisticated surrogate models  such as adding a variance processes to track changes in noise throughout the input space, or relaxing the Gaussian assumptions. Appropriate surrogate modeling is key to the propagation of uncertainty to decision criteria underlying important large-scale and real time control of systems which rely on expensive simulation campaigns. Think of estimating the stretching effect in observing the light of far-away galaxies with future satellite campaigns, from existing incomplete data and realistic synthetic data. Or similarly the combination of limited data on disease spread combined with fine-grained simulation of epidemiological dynamics and entertainment of intervention strategies such as vaccination or quarantine. The talks will be on these methodologies applied in those challenging modeling and optimization of large scale real-world problems.

meeting.EventName: MS69 Model-Based Optimal Experimental Design - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: The challenge of acquiring useful data from experimentsfor the purpose of inference, prediction, design, or controlhas received substantial attention. This task can be formalized through the framework of optimal experimental design (OED), and guided by models (whether physical or statistical) that can simulate the experimental conditions and processes. However, model-based OED faces many difficulties, such as in choosing optimality criteria, computing information metrics, quantifying uncertainties, handling nonlinear responses and non-Gaussian distributions, and accommodating expensive and dynamically evolving simulations. This minisymposium invites contributions that advance the algorithms, computations, and applications of model-based OED.

meeting.EventName: MS7 Operator Learning in PDEs, Inverse Problems, and UQ - Part I of II
meeting.EventDescription: Operators that map functions to functions are fundamental in science and engineering, often modeling physical laws or complex engineering systems, and it is desirable to learn such operators for the purpose of scientific discovery or surrogate modeling. This is especially relevant for inverse problems, as not only is the act of learning itself an inverse problem, but once an efficient and scalable surrogate operator is learned, it can then be used to accelerate expensive inverse computations such as UQ, Bayesian inversion, and optimal design, or even directly output the inverse problem solution. Although model-driven and physics-based approaches were originally developed for these tasks, in recent years data-driven methods have also exhibited remarkable success. However, the mathematical understanding of learning operators from data, including estimation, approximation, and optimization errors, is still in its infancy. This minisymposium brings together researchers working in statistical machine learning, approximation theory, Bayesian inference, and PDEs to discuss recent theoretical and methodological advances in operator learning motivated by both forward and inverse problems.

meeting.EventName: MS70 Learning Dynamics and the Dynamics of Learning - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Dynamical systems are one of the most important tools to model processes in science and engineering. With the increasing availability of data, there has been significant interest in developing pathways between dynamical systems and data to obtain more accurate descriptions or prediction of states in real world applications. This `Learning of dynamics' has been investigated/considered in different communities and applications, for example in data assimilation in Bayesian inversion, physics-informed neural networks, or statistical inverse problems in dynamical systems. On the other hand, many processes and models in modern data science and machine learning are based on underlying dynamical systems. Examples include residual neural networks, which can be related to discretization of ODEs, the stochastic gradient descent algorithm, which generates a discrete in time stochastic process, and time-dependent partial differential equations that are used for classification of graphical data.
This minisymposium on modeling and blending learning dynamics with data, will provide an inter-disciplinary platform to discuss recent developments in the respective fields, in particular differences and similarities of analytic and computational methodologies. The minisymposium aims at facilitating interdisciplinary discussions and collaborations, to create synergies and explore novel research directions.

meeting.EventName: MS71 Data-Centric Machine Learning for Uncertainty Quantification in Complex Systems - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Multiscale models, multiphysics models, and network systems are part of complex systems, the modeling of which is computationally expensive. This expense is exacerbated when performing uncertainty quantification (UQ) studies for tasks such as inverse parameter estimation, rare events analysis, and optimal design and control. By allowing the machine learning (ML) model to assess the quality of the training data and further pick subsequent training data for optimizing performance, data-centric ML can provide a computationally tractable framework for UQ studies involving complex systems. However, several challenges such as robustness and efficiency of UQ for ML model predictions, algorithmic scalability, enforcement of physical constraints, and use of parallel computing need to be addressed for enhancing data-centric ML models in the computational sciences. This minisymposium focuses on the recent advances in algorithms, frameworks, methodologies, and applications that promote data-centric ML in the computational sciences. Because advancing data-centric ML requires research in ML, statistics and probability, and the domain of interest, all topics directly addressing or supporting data-centric ML are welcome in this minisymposium. These include, but are not limited to, approximate inference, stochastic differential equation-driven and hybrid MCMC, quality of UQ for ML models, UQ with parallel computing, Bayesian Neural Nets, Reinforcement Learning, and applications.

meeting.EventName: MS72 Operator Learning for Uncertainty Quantification - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Operator learning techniques have recently emerged as a powerful tool for learning mappings between infinite-dimensional function spaces. Techniques such as deep operator networks, the family of neural operator methods, and operator-valued kernel methods have demonstrated promise in building fast surrogate models for emulating complex physical processes, opening new avenues for sampling, inference and uncertainty quantification in very high-dimensional parameter spaces. This minisymposium invites contributions that demonstrate the power of operator learning methods in the context of uncertainty quantification, from both a methodological and applications point of view.

meeting.EventName: MS73 Remote Sensing Inverse Problems for Understanding Atmospheric Greenhouse Gases - Part II of II
meeting.EventDescription:
Changing atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations, particularly carbon dioxide, represent a substantial perturbation to the global climate system. Understanding the resulting responses to carbon storage in the atmosphere, land, and oceans, as well as their interactions with other parts of the climate system, remains a substantial challenge in Earth science. Through global coverage and fine spatial and temporal resolution, a growing constellation of satellites are providing meaningful additional information on the carbon cycle. However, satellite observations are subject to multiple stages of processing before estimates of surface-atmosphere carbon exchange, known as fluxes, are produced. Importantly, this processing involves multiple inferences based on ill-posed inverse problems subject to several sources of uncertainty.
The first inverse problem, known as a retrieval, aims to estimate atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations from the satellite spectra. Several of the mini-symposium presentations will highlight aspects of operational and/or alternative retrieval approaches and explore the computational tradeoffs for physical and statistical models of varying fidelity in the inference. Carbon cycle science investigations use the retrievals' outputs in further inference, including flux inversion. The final presentations will address additional sources of uncertainty for carbon cycle inference.

meeting.EventName: MS74 Verification Techniques in Computational Physics and Applied Mathematics - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription:
In computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes, verification and validation of the implementation and suitability of the governing equations are necessary to develop confidence in the credibility of the simulations. Verification assesses the accuracy of the solutions the code produces, relative to the assumptions and expectations of the numerical methods. Verification results also depend acutely upon the regularity of the solution. This association is delicate in the presence of singularities.
Verification can be divided into code and solution verification. Code verification focuses on the correctness of the numerical-method implementation in the code; solution verification focuses on numerical-error estimation for simulations as part of uncertainty quantification. Code verification is typically checked using manufactured and exact solutions and mesh-refinement studies. On the other hand, mesh-refinement studies are not the only techniques to perform error estimation. However, most of the proposed techniques require meshes in the so-called 'asymptotic range'. This requirement makes solution verification practically troublesome. Topics of interest include manufactured solutions, exact solutions, and other code-verification techniques, error-estimation (solution-verification) techniques, for computational-physics and applied-mathematics codes.

meeting.EventName: MS75 Efficient Uncertainty Quantification with Physics-Informed and Data-Driven Models - Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: Quantifying the uncertainty in a model is crucial to establishing trust in its predictions. The cost of running high-fidelity physics-based models makes proper uncertainty analysis untenable, motivating the need for data-driven surrogate models. However, data-driven models may miss critical physics and properties of the system under investigation. This minisymposium features methods for informing and constraining the underlying physics of data driven and machine-learned models for prediction and uncertainty quantification. We invite researchers to contribute talks that advance the field of physics-informed data-driven modeling for computationally efficient calibration, validation, and uncertainty quantification.

meeting.EventName: MS76 Nonlinear Model Reduction Methods for Random or Parametric Time Dependent Problems - Part III of III
meeting.EventDescription: Model order reduction is an effective strategy to address problems with (possibly random) parameters. The idea is to project the underlying equations onto a small finite dimensional subspace spanned by few cleverly constructed deterministic modes thus leading to a reduced size problem on which UQ or parametric analysis can be cheaply performed by e.g. sampling or quadrature techniques. However, for time dependent problems with complex dynamics, the optimal subspace on which to approximate the solution at each time instant can considerably change over time. We address in this minisymposium recent advances in model reduction for evolution problems. These include nonlinear model reduction methods or dynamical methods for the construction of time varying reduced spaces, for instance, local-adaptive-transformed reduced basis methods as well as dynamical low rank tensor approximations.

meeting.EventName: MS77 Advanced Multilevel and Multifidelity UQ Strategies: Applications, Generalized Model Hierarchies, and Data-Driven Approaches -- Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Uncertainty Quantification for high-fidelity and application-relevant computations at scale remains challenging due to the extreme computational burden and the potentially large number of parameters inherent to complex physics models. Many multifidelity strategies have been introduced to circumvent these challenges, and promising results have been obtained for a variety of large-scale applications. Common to these strategies is the fusion of information with differing degrees of cost and accuracy, to ensure sufficient accuracy while reducing computational expense. This minisymposium focuses on the latest advances in multilevel and multifidelity algorithms for uncertainty quantification leveraging multiple sources of simulation and experimental data. Among the topics presented are applications to challenging industrial, nonlinear, and/or stochastic problems; methods for generalized model hierarchies including model tuning and online estimators; and data-driven approaches.

meeting.EventName: MS78 Methods for Hierarchical Bayesian Inverse Problems - Part II of III
meeting.EventDescription: Many problems in Bayesian statistics involve the combination of complex models with sparse observed data. In such cases, the data alone might be unable to identify the model parameters and valid inferences will require significant prior information. This can be performed by specification of a hierarchical model, where extra nuisance parameters or 'hyperparameters' are used to add robustness to the prior. Computing the posterior solution via Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling is a oftentimes a challenge, since the geometry of the target posterior density can change abruptly after small variations in the hyperparameters. This minisymposium aims to cover recent advances and applications in hierarchical Bayesian inverse problems, including for instance, estimation of regularization parameters, Gibbs samplers, marginalization approaches, among others.

meeting.EventName: MS79 Uncertainty, Robustness and Safety in Deep Learning Part I of III
meeting.EventDescription: There has been increasing interest in ensuring that deep learning are reliable, safe and robust. Challenges arise when models receive samples drawn from outside the training distribution. Anomalies are frequently encountered when deploying ML models in the real world. Well-calibrated predictive uncertainty estimates are indispensable for many ML applications. Generalization to unseen and worst-case inputs is also essential for robustness to distributional shift. To have ML models safely deployed in open environments, we must deepen technical understanding: 1) learning algorithms that can detect changes in data distribution and improve out-of-distribution (OOD) generalization; 2) Guide learning towards an understanding of the underlying causal mechanisms for improving robustness and generalization and enforcing distributional invariances. To achieve these goals, it is critical to dedicate substantial effort on studying key applications of robust and uncertainty-aware deep learning as well as broader ML tasks. Through the minisymposium we hope to help identify fundamentally important directions on robust and reliable ML and foster future collaborations.
